com/home/pib Real-time vision-based multiple object tracking of a production process: Industrial digital twin case study Robert Ward1 , Payam Soulatiantork1, Shaun Finneran2, Ruby Hughes2 and Ashutosh Tiwari1 Abstract The adoption of Industry 4

0 technologies within the manufacturing and process industries is widely accepted to have benefits for production cycles, increase system flexibility and give production managers more options on the production line through reconfigurable systems
A key enabler in Industry 4
0 technology is the rise in Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) and Digital Twins (DTs)
Both technologies connect the physical to the cyber world in order to generate smart manufac- turing capabilities

State of the art research accurately describes the frameworks, challenges and advantages surrounding these technologies but fails to deliver on testbeds and case studies that can be used for development and validation
This research demonstrates a novel proof of concept Industry 4
0 production system which lays the foundations for future research in DT technologies, process optimisation and manufacturing data analytics
Using a connected system of com- mercial off-the-shelf cameras to retrofit a standard programmable logic controlled production process, a digital simula- tion is updated in real time to create the DT
The system can identify and accurately track the product through the production cycle whilst updating the DT in real-time
The implemented system is a lightweight, low cost, customable and scalable design solution which provides a testbed for practical Industry 4
0 research both for academic and industrial research purposes
Keywords Digital twin, cyber-physical production systems, multiple object tracking, real time vision tracking, smart manufacturing, industry 4
0 Date received: 25 January 2021; accepted: 14 February 2021 Introduction Manufacturing systems are dramatically changing as a result of the Fourth Industrial Revolution (IR4
0) and the increase in the digitisation of the manufacturing industry
1,2 Global competitiveness has amplified the need for manufacturers to be reactive and adaptive to increasingly diverse customer demands and on much shorter time scales than ever before
These factors lead to increased complexity and a reduction in decision time within the manufacturing system, both of which require intelligent and innovative technologies
Two such technologies that are addressing these manufacturing challenges are the CPS3–5 and the DT
6,7 Each have similar attributes such that they seek to con- nect the physical with the cyber world using a variety of communication methods
A CPS focuses on the interac- tion between the two worlds whereas the DT provides a complete digital description of the physical process
Each can consist of interconnected sensors and commu- nication networks which may include cloud and/or edge computing
8–10 A DT is a digital representation of a physical asset
The degree of complexity of the DT, which can be a realtime or predictive representation a system, is spe- cific to the intended use of the DT

DTs can represent different types of system behaviour and levels of com- plexity within the system depending on the user 1Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, UK 2Manufacturing Intelligence, Factory 2050, Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, UK Corresponding author: Robert Ward, Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering, The University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, UK

11,12 They can be applied to all stages in the product lifecycle from prototyping through to pro- duction
Specific to the manufacturing industry, when a DT and CPS is deployed into production environment it is termed a Cyber-Physical Production system (CPPS)
The digitisation of the shop floor has ensured more accurate and timely information flows which has improved reporting times, reduced reporting errors and aided process planning flexibility
The secondary bene- fit of digitisation has been the availability of data for Prognostic and Health Management (PHM) applica- tions
In a modern production process there exists a need for integration between the factory floor automa- tion level and the Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) level
Interfacing between these two levels is the Manufacturing Execution System (MES) and the func- tion of the MES to control production lines in order to meet the business strategy
13,14 The MES provides a required level of situational awareness of the produc- tion process and in order to improve the fidelity and accuracy of the system a CPPS is required

The CPPS can be both real-time, to assist time-critical decision making, and also predictive to enable planners off-line solutions to on-line problems thereby removing any unnecessary costs of plant downtime
15 With an ever increasing and complex set of requirements for the fac- tory of the future there is a requirement for a DT and CPPS to operate in real-time

The production manag- ers and operators then have the ability to view the whole production system from the unit level through to the operational level and have complete visibility of the operating capacity, overall equipment effectiveness (OEE) and full control of the ERP
An integral component of a CPS is Machine to Machine communication (M2M)
M2M includes any communication between machines, controllers and actuators using both wired and wireless networks
M2M is a key part of Internet of Things (IoT) net- works and there is a host of commercial and open- source protocols which have been designed for the manufacturing sector
16 MTConnect and OPC-Unified Architecture (OPC-UA) are two communication proto- cols specifically designed for industrial automation

17,18 MTConnect has been designed towards the Computer Numerical Control (CNC) machine shop with prede- fined data structures and rules whereas OPC-UA pro- vides a more open user-defined variable structure which results in a wider scope of implementation
19 OPC-UA has the capability to both receive and send information where MTConnect can only monitor
The use of OPC-UA has been an enabling technology in this research
The challenge within the CPS context is to use the available data in a smart manner to improve productiv- ity, accurately predict system response and reduce sys- tem downtime
20 Therefore, the same information that is used to update the MES (PLC and M2M data) can be used to update the DT
One source of real-time data is programmable logic controller (PLC)
21 Significant process data can be accessed from the PLC such as counters for throughput metrics or from radio- frequency identification (RFID)
22–24 tags on pallets
Pallets are load carrying components of a production line that transport the product around the plant during the various phases of production
The RFID tags con- tain electronically stored information and use electro- magnetic fields to enable automatic identification and tracking whilst attached to objects
The RFID tags located in the pallets can be read by RFID sensors at strategic points around the production system
The use of RFID tags to assist tracking in manufacturing assembly lines has been a proven capability for many years

25,26 Placing RFID sensors at strategic locations around a manufacturing plant, such as at stations and loading/unloading platforms, then the MES can be kept up-to-date with the state of the production plant
The data from RFID tags can be sent to the MES either via PLC communication or through one of the many M2M communication methods

When RFID object detection is set far at a distance from the sensor then signal strength can lead to difficulty in detection therefore methods have combined RFID with com- puter vision techniques27,28 to improve detection and tracking
The technologies described above (RFID, PLC, Fast M2M communications) are all key compo- nents to a successful CPPS and DT
It has been demonstrated that conducting research on teaching platforms can aid development of Industry 4
0 technologies
A detailed review of manufacturing and production testbeds for teaching and research is presented in Abele et al
29 The research highlighted that many legacy testbeds were designed for a specific man- ufacturing teaching goal
Many testbeds were designed to teach production principles pre-Industry 4
0, there- fore, there is now a shift to develop demonstrators for smart manufacturing30 and Industry 4
0 technologies
Some examples are now discussed

The iFactory, housed with the Intelligent Manufacturing Systems31 Center at Windsor, Canada is a reconfigurable manufacturing plant focused on sys- tems learning, re-configurable processes and product design and customisation
The Experimental and Digital Factory32 at the Chemnitz University of Technology consists of networked laboratories used for teaching various aspects of manufacturing processes
The Smart Factory KL33 at the Technical University of Kaiserslautern consists of a testbed with many of the key communication technologies used within this research such as RFID and networked systems
The facility demonstrates a liquid soap manufacturing sys- tem
The Smart Factory,34 at the Fraunhofer Project Center at MTA SZATKI in Hungary, is a compact production facility which explores physical and virtual manufacturing processes

The Smart Production Laboratory (Smart Lab)35 at Aalborg University con- sists of reconfigurable cells interconnected with con- veyor systems with research focused on emerging 2 Proc IMechE Part B: J Engineering Manufacture 00(0) digital technologies such as virtual commissioning
Both the MTA SZATKI and Aalborg plants initially focused research on the cyber physical production system and both will subsequently benefit from applied digital twin research
Other similar modular systems include I4
0 Lab36 at Politecnico di Milano, SmartPro4
037 at Zurich University of Applied Sciences, Swiss Smart Factory38 at the Switzerland Innovation Park, Bern and the Industry 4
0 Pilot Factory (I40PF)39 at the Technical University of Vienna
These centres all offer a multitude of smart manufacturing capabilities but have yet to take the CPPS or Digital Twin research to publication

And finally, in terms of production line tracking, a computer integrated manufacturing scenario40 implemented a vision based tracking system to a production line teach- ing demonstrator which resulted in position updates every 25 s to a cloud based system for visualisation
Few studies have demonstrated the implementation of a real-time production DT for Industry 4
0 research
There is a need for practical research testbeds to demonstrate and publish future technologies for the manufacturing sector
This includes research for the factory of the future and for the transition of legacy factories to become IR4
0 capable
Ribeirio and Bjorkman41 described the challenges from transitioning from a standard automation system to a CPPS and Uhleman et al
42 highlighted the need for scalable demonstrator platforms to demonstrate the IR4
0 prin- ciples where the requirements included the need for real-time data acquisition to support DTs
There exists a gap in research demonstrating produc- tion digital twin capable testbeds
The platforms are required to develop and validate future practical indus- try 4
0 technology and research, moving away from the theoretical structures and frameworks described in liter- ature and providing tangible results based research outputs
In this paper the authors demonstrate a proof of concept implementation which fills that gap in the research in order to provide a testbed for further aca- demic and industrial research
Intended research appli- cations include digital twin research, production process optimisation and manufacturing data analytics

Paper organisation This paper is organised as fol- lows, first, the physical description of the CPPS lab is described, second, the development of the DT model is presented, third, the development of the vision tracking system is presented and finally the results of the system implementation are discussed
Cyber physical production system CPPS description The CPPS Lab, housed at the University of Sheffield, is a modular Industry 4
0 learning system from FESTO Didactic
The system is representative of a modern industrial production line which is fitted with the cap- abilities to demonstrate and communicate with Industry 4
0 methodologies and standards
Figure 1 shows the key components defined within automation level framework
The production factory consists of many work stations interconnected by conveyor trans- port systems
The CPPS Lab consists of a remote PC terminal, two work stations and a pallet carrying robot station named Robotino
The physical system layout is divided into two work stations (as shown in Figure 2)
Each work station consists of four hardware modules which are further broken down into three application modules and one bridge pallet transfer module
The four modules are connected in a loop configuration as shown in Figure 3
The pallet can be loaded or unloaded from each work station using the bridge pal- let transfer module
The Robotino carries the pallets Figure 1
Automation level framework showing the key components of the cyber physical production system laboratory
Ward et al
3 between the two bridge pallet transfer modules which act as docking stations
The six application modules each represent a part of a standard industrial manufacturing process

The spe- cific function of the CPPS Lab is a mobile phone pro- duction line where upper and lower panels of a mobile phone case are joined together and heat treated before being removed from the conveyor system for unload- ing
Numbered pallets move around the production line; stopping at each station to carry out the respective function
Each pallet contains an RFID chip that is read by sensors situated at each station for pallet identi- fication

The application modules consist of the follow- ing functions (in order) – Magazine application (front panel), height measuring module, magazine application (back panel), pneumatic press, tunnel heater and finally an output module for physical removal from the pro- duction line
All eight modules consist of a pallet carrying con- veyor system, a series of sensors (including an RFID sensor), a PLC and in-built OPC-UA servers as shown in Figure 4
The layout is shown in Figure 3
The appli- cation modules are controlled by Siemens S7 ET200SP PLCs with Siemens TP700 touch panel human machine interfaces (HMIs)
The PLCs are each connected to a PROFINET via RJ45 connections
The PROFINET communicates with the local PC which hosts the MES via an OPC-UA server for production orders, system status and maintenance functions
The two bridge mod- ules are controlled by FESTO PLCs using CoDeSys software connected to the local PC via an OPC-UA server
UA Expert was used as an OPC-UA client dur- ing system testing and for monitoring purposes
Digital twin Within this research, the DT is termed a ‘Simulation DT’, the systems’ behaviour is represented through Discrete Event Simulation (DES)
It is concerned with the movement of parts through the system which is dri- ven by discrete events such as operations upon the part
It is not be concerned with simulating the intricacies of the operations themselves and the physics involved
This can be considered the level of abstraction of the DT
The usefulness of this type of DT for a factory, for example, comes though the virtual replica (simulation) of the factory being actively linked to the physical fac- tory floor

The DT can hence monitor the factory, identify issues or sub-optimal behaviour, re-optimise the factory virtually (within the simulation) and, upon approval, implement these changes back into the physi- cal factory via connected control systems, all performed within decision critical times
A DES model representing the ‘as-is’ simulation DT of the cell was created using Siemens Tecnomatix PlantSim software
43 A DES model was used as it has the ability to use measured data in order to accurately model the future behaviour and states of the production process
The model captures the physical and digital behaviour of the cell
The model uses a functional model to represent the individual stations and conveyor system overlaid with a CAD model as viewed in Figure 5
Combined the system gives a realistic visualisation of the real-world system (as shown in Figure 6)

The DES model can display RFID Information (Pallet ID), num- ber and position of parts in the system at a given time based on touch sensors and RFID tag detection when in station, cycle times of a production process duration at any given station and goods-in/goods-out
PlantSim reads the real-time data from the eight PLCs in the phys- ical cell via OPC-UA
Each PLC hosts an OPC-UA ser- ver with one for each station
It is through this OPC-UA server that the real-time vision system data is hosted
The DES model provides important information to the user but it is the overlay of the high-fidelity CAD Figure 2

This is a key component to DTs where the user is able to better visualise the status of real-world system without being physically on-site
Ensuring an accurate visual representation of the status of the system is one of the objectives of a DT
In a large factory setting one of the advantages of this type of DT would be the rapid diagnosis of the location of a fault
If a pallet became stuck or there was a sensor fault then it is easy for main- tenance teams to visualise where the physical location of the problem is and react quickly
This type of tech- nology is rapidly expanding into Augmented Reality maintenance systems aided by DT technologies
Implementation Vision tracking system
The objective of the vision track- ing system was to create a low cost solution to identify, accurately track and transmit the position of the pallets to the CPPS DT in real-time

5 tracking system are the four video feeds of the pallets moving along the conveyors and the pallet RFID infor- mation read at each station
The output was defined to be an OPC-UA data structure with updated pallet num- ber, position and order on each conveyor
The system was designed to be stand alone which then can be used by the DT to retrieve the data as desired
It has no func- tion into the control or operation of the lab, therefore it can be turned on or off without disrupting the produc- tion process
Hardware
The vision tracking system consists of four D435 Intel�RealSense� depth cameras connected to a Dell Optiplex 5050 CPU (Intel i5-7500 3
4GHz, 8GB 2400MHZ DDR4, Windows 10 Pro OS) via USB3 cables
The D435 cameras are configured for depth and colour streaming which provide intrinsic and extrinsic calibration capabilities
44 The D435 cameras have excellent low light sensitivity due to the global shutter sensor and a wide field of view which makes them suitable for a range of industrial environments
The mounted positions can be see in Figure 7 and the corresponding four video feeds can be seen in Figure 8
The cameras are co-labelled with the station they are viewing, for example camera 4 is viewing station 4
The CPU is housed within the CPPS infrastructure and is connected to the PROFINET via RJ45 cable
Each camera is mounted such that it is positioned to view the whole of the individual conveyor and multiple pal- lets that are transferred along the conveyor

6 Proc IMechE Part B: J Engineering Manufacture 00(0) � Track Manager- bespoke software – once object detections have been performed they are passed to the track manager
This calculates the cost of assigning each detected pallet to each existing track, and then assigns them in the most cost effective manner
Pallet detection system An overview of pallet detection process is shown in Appendix 1
The vision tracking system can be sum- marised into object detection, assignment and tracking, ID assignments, conveyor arrival and departure and communication
The methodology is explained in the following section
Input and object detection The process initialises when a video feed is received from the D435 cameras
The Intel RealSense video frame is converted to an OpenCV matrix
The pallet is detected as an object using the Yolo detector deep neural network which has been cross trained using pre- vious video footage of the conveyors
Once detected, a bounding box is applied to contain the object (the pal- let)
The software looks in the surrounding area for the object features in the following frames
The detection is called every four frames – in between the detection frames, a Kalman Filter is used to estimate the position
The estimated position is updated after each detection frame
This optimises the CPU to reduce processor usage as a Kalman Filter is more efficient on the CPU memory than the Yolo object detection algorithm

A pallet located in the station and behind the struts can be seen in Figure 10, the red bounding box is clearly seen with the pallet ID number, order on conveyor (for when there are multiple pallets on the conveyor) and distance along the conveyor
Assignment and tracking Difficulties arose when the objects passed behind the struts of the modules, where all tracking algorithms failed to track objects
In order to overcome this, the Kalman Filter was used to estimate the pallets next positions based on the previous estimation and detected position of the pallet
This enables the system to track the object as it passes behind the struts

7 A cost array is generated and then calculated to assign predictions to tracks
The Hungarian algo- rithm49,50 (also known as Kuhn-Munkres algorithm) is then applied to assign predictions to tracks by minimis- ing the cost
The Hungarian algorithm is used for two purposes, one, to map each observed detection to a track, and two, for multiple object tracking
Object Detection to Track Mapping The algorithm uses data from two adjacent frames to link each obser- vation to a track

The Euclidean distance between an object in two frames (k and k + 1) is the key metric in the assignment matrices Dk, k + 1, Dk, k+1 = d1k, 1k+1 d1k, 2k+1 d1k, 3k+1 d2k, 1k+1 d2k, 2k+1 d2k, 3k+1 d3k, 1k+1 d3k, 2k+1 d3k, 3k+1 where, dik, jk+1 =Euclidian distance Oi, k,Oj, k+1 The algorithm finds the mapping between the two objects by minimising the solution of the assignment matrices as follows: f=Min Dk, k+1f gð Þ f : O1, k+1 ! O1, kð Þ, O2, k+1 ! O3, kð Þf g j Oi, k,Oi, k+1 2 R2 In this implementation of the Hungarian algorithm, the cost function is based on the Euclidean distance in the x axis between detected object position in the Yolo net- work and the updated state estimate from the Kalman Filter
Previously assigned tracks are updated and new tracks are created for any unassigned detections
Tracks that have expired or not assigned for 15 frames are deleted
Multiple Object Tracking More than one pallet can be on a conveyor at any time
Therefore the vision tracking system must be capable of multiple object tracking
To do this, the Hungarian algorithm associ- ates an object from one frame to another based on a score
A common approach is to use the IOU (Intersection Over Union) which means that if the bounding box in next frame overlaps the bounding box in the current frame then it is likely the same object
The algorithm can tell if an object is new, if it has moved, or if it is stationary, as shown in Figure 11
In the Yolo detector, two lists are generated, a track- ing list and a detection list
A cost function gives a weight to each score and stores these in a matrix
The maximum and minimum weights are 1 and 0, respec- tively
A score of 1 would represent an exact match of a bounding box in two frames
The matrix describes the mapping between the detections and the tracks
The Hungarian algorithm uses bipartite graph theory to calculate each detection
The individual detections and now mapped to the individual tracks
Each cycle generates matched detections, unmatched detections and unmatched tracks
Multiple pallet tracking can be seen in Figure 12

ID assignment, conveyor arrival and departure As each pallet is fitted with an RFID chip, when a pal- let enters a station the RFID sensor reads the pallet information and sends the data through the PROFINET to the OPC-UA server
The software assigns the pallet ID to the detected object as can be seen in Figure 10
As the pallet is transferred along the production line the vision system continually tracks the pallet and calculates the pallet position
When the pal- let is about to leave a conveyor, the next conveyor is waiting to detect a new object
The new object is auto- matically assigned the pallet ID from the pallet that has just left the previous conveyor
This enables contin- uous tracking and pallet identification around the whole conveyor circuit
The system has the capability to detect four pallets on each conveyor, therefore each conveyor is assigned four sets of tags
The tag sets are presented in terms of ranked position order, that is, 1st, 2nd, 3rd or 4th and contain pallet ID and positional information (mm) along the conveyor
However, due to the time taken in station to read the pallet ID, only three pallets can be Figure 11

The ability to conduct multiple object tracking is important for scalability to real industrial processes where the conveyor tracks can be anywhere from 0
5 to 20m and beyond
System output The output from the pallet detection system is read by the DT via OPC-UA
The DT can read the data in real time and update the visual position of the pallet on the functional model
With the CAD overlay this provides an accurate visual representation of the physical system as shown in Figure 13
The pallet ID and position is continuously updated on the OPC-UA server as opposed the previous method where the DT was only provided up to date information at RFID sensor posi- tions
Two pallets can be seen in Figure 13 where the positions have been updated on the DT and the result is an accurate representation of the real world system
Research platform The real-time DT (as presented in Figure 13) is now a baseline platform for Industry 4
0 research
The cap- abilities demonstrated include real-time data monitor- ing, multiple object tracking and real-time DT visualisations
These foundation capabilities are enablers which allow further research in DT and CPPS technologies from multi-disciplinary areas from engi- neering through to operational business research

The use of industrial PLC devices, OPC-UA communica- tion and commercial-off-the-shelf hardware and soft- ware ensure that the DT can scale directly into an industrial setting and the industrial research developed on the platform can translate to a production process
Conclusions This paper has demonstrated that a Cyber Physical Production System can be generated for an existing industrial production plant
Using existing PLC infor- mation, a vision based multiple object tracking system has been implemented to provide accurate real-time product identification and position throughout the plant
The real-time information provides inputs to a visual discrete event model via an OPC-UA server which results in an accurate real-time DT and visual representation of the industrial process
This low cost, reconfigurable and scalable technology is an excellent testbed for future Industry 4
0 research
The focus of this research has been to demonstrate a proof of concept system for Industry 4
0 research
The next step is to integrate this information with the MES in order to optimise product launch scheduling and prove the utility of real-time plant information to opti- mise resource planning

In the immediate future, the research effort will extend the current level of simula- tion and focus on a multi-level DT of the FESTO sys- tem with the aim of DT at each level in the automation pyramid (see Figure 1)

uk  Document revision history Executive summary Model Based Definition can be defined as: “The use of a single 3D model (“single source of truth”), based on a common framework, as the sole design reference for a product” Similarly, Model Based Enterprise can be defined as: “The use of a 3D model as the sole reference for multiple manufacturing processes across a product’s manufacturing cycle”  Broadly speaking, Model Based Enterprise (MBE) is the use of a 3D geometry as the single  reference for the production of a part or assembly, Model Based Definition (MBD) is the use of a single 3D model as the design reference only
That is, a model designed through MBD will be  annotated with all information required for manufacture, such as GD&T data and bills of  material

In an MBE process, this model is passed between departments, suppliers and clients  without the necessity for traditional 2D paper drawings and may be used in processes such as  manufacturing and inspection

This comes with a multitude of potential advantages, including facilitating the improvement of  production rate, providing a more intuitive interface for end users, and providing a more  reliable and robust method for the storage of inspection data
However, there are also a  number of limitations, such as software functionality, difficulties in incorporating legacy  products and overcoming resistance to change from end users and supply chains
The academic literature around the subject demonstrates various methods for the  implementation of frameworks and how to implement a general MBE approach
It also indicates that there are clear financial benefits to the implementation of MBE, and that industry either  uses or is generally receptive to its use
This report presents an extension of this work by surveying the AMRC’s partner companies to  understand their perceptions of MBD, specifically
Quality improvement and better presentation of data were seen as key benefits, while current software capability and associated upskilling  were identified as problems to overcome
The respondents also provided their own definitions,  and analysis of these reinforced the view that the storage of data in a single model is the key  feature of MBD
Finally a demonstrator was developed to show an application of an MBE-based approach for an  inspection process, described within this report
The demonstrator consisted of a KUKA iiwa  fitted with a camera, this being used to inspect the hole geometry of some motor retention  brackets
This inspection information was attached to the 3D model of the brackets, along with  various other types of data to provide a reference for other potential processes

uk  1 Introduction Model Based Definition (MBD) describes the use of a 3D model as sole reference for all design  data for a component or assembly
This can be extended by Model Based Enterprise (MBE),  which is the use of a digital model as the sole reference for all stages across the manufacturing process
The use of these techniques has the potential for delivering cost, quality and time  savings into a manufacturing process, but their use is not pervasive within the Engineering  community

1 Project overview This CATAPULT project was initiated to allow the AMRC to develop a more robust understanding of MBD and MBE, what benefits these can deliver to industry, and how these potential benefits  can be realised by both top tier companies and their supply chain

The project also identified  areas where development is required in the practical implementation of MBD and MBE  approaches, and specifically explored the current state of the implementation of MBD within  industry
Finally, it delivered a practical demonstration of a MBE process
2 Report objectives This report is intended to be one of the two main deliverables of the project, alongside the  demonstrator described in section

It has three main objectives:  Provide a high-level overview of the principles behind MBD and MBE, its potential  advantages and barriers to implementation, and current academic and industrial  practice around it  Provide an indication of current attitudes from industrial partners to MBD and MBE, and use this to suggest practical steps for the implementation of such approaches  Describe the demonstrator developed to showcase the MBE approach to manufacturing Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 7 of 51 Confidential
Copyright © The University of Sheffield / Apr-21 AMRC
Template detail: AMRC
RP Revision 16 (December 2018)
For information about this template contact:  qande@amrc
co
uk  2 General definitions 2
1 Model Based Definition Model Based Definition (MBD) is a manufacturing methodology that utilises the 3D CAD model  of the product as the sole design reference
This differs from the common method of using 2D  drawings as the primary source of information about a product, with supplemental 3D models  being used for design and development work
The goal of this approach is to reduce the  amount of superfluous documents and drawings, improve the consistency of the data used,  and to enable better virtualization of a product or process

However, it does not necessarily  remove traditional 2D drawings from the design process if they are the most suitable  presentation format of the product information – it simply removes them as the primary source  of information
Figure   2
1 shows the conversion from a traditional 2D drawing as a source of information to a 3D model
The same information is retained in the model but is better presented, with only  relevant information shown to the user via an interactive 3D PDF
The most obvious benefit to  this is the intuitive viewing and presentation of the model, with this having clear applications in the generation of digital work instructions

However, the key benefit to the storage of data in a  single model is that there is the potential for a significant decrease in product manufacturing  time, arising as a result of fewer conflicts between design changes
This leads to faster analysis and approval of any changes, more intuitive instructions during manufacture and the potential  for two way data exchange being used to make in-process improvements
Figure 2

1 - A traditional 2D drawing (L) and the corresponding model displayed in an interactive 3D PDF (R) An MBD-based methodology broadly consists of annotating a 3D model with any information  relevant to the manufacture of the product
Known as PMI (Product Manufacturing Information)  this can consist of any of the traditional information stored in a 2D drawing, such as  dimensions, tolerances and material
This is related to the Common Information Model, which is a model that contains information relevant to all stages of the product’s manufacturing process (i
e
design, manufacture and inspection)

There are a number of factors to consider during the  definition of the Common Information Model and PMI, with these being listed below [1]:  Required contents - At the most fundamental level, it is important to consider what  details are necessary to transmit sufficient manufacturing information in a 3D CAD model  GD & T information - To enable the manufacture of a component it is important that the  model contains adequate tolerances, dimensions and other geometric definitions Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 8 of 51 Confidential
Copyright © The University of Sheffield / Apr-21 AMRC
Template detail: AMRC
RP Revision 16 (December 2018)
For information about this template contact:  qande@amrc
co

uk   Relevant information - Information stored in the model should be strictly relevant to the  process  Basic characteristics - The model must conform with the standards for the organisation  implementing an MBD approach, such as naming conventions, base coordinate systems,  notes etc

 Security - The implementation of an MBD approach must not generate any process  security flaws  Standardization - Product meta-data should be standardized across an organisation if  possible as this allows interaction between various company systems (ERP, MES, CRM  etc

)  Singular file data - All data should be kept in a single file, allowing easier access to all  users, and reducing manually reproduced data An MBD approach is defined using a framework, which describes how information (e
g
tolerances and dimensions) flows through a manufacturing process
Frameworks are used in  the development of tools for accessing and acting on this information
They are informed  through the analysis of workflows, which describe specific areas of work within a manufacturing process

2 Model Based Enterprise Model Based Enterprise (MBE) extends the MBD methodology from a process or product to the  entire workflow of an organisation, using the 3D model generated as a single source of truth to  which relevant data is appended
As such, the model may be used as a common reference for  processes including design, manufacturing, inspection, marketing and any other processes that may require product engagement

The utilisation of common product models for the definition, execution, control and  management of enterprise wide operations can lead to the reduction of time and cost of the  development and delivery of that product

Some industry leaders have estimated that MBE  could reduce costs by up to 50% and reduce time to market by 45%, however, they do go on to state that these goals are aggressive and would require significant investment to be achieved [2]
The benefits delivered by an MBE approach may also better facilitate the incorporation of  modelling and validation techniques into the design and analysis process
3 Benefits and limitations MBD and MBE deliver similar benefits and suffer from similar limitations, which are described in this section
However, it is clear that the benefits would be most pronounced where both  approaches are used in tandem

Given its reliance on the ‘digital thread’ – that is, the digital  linkage of all production processes – it is clear that MBE is reliant on an MBD implementation to deliver improvements to the manufacturing process
1 Benefits The primary advantages to MBD and MBE are derived from the transition to a paperless  system, as the model itself contains all the information required for the manufacturing process
The advantages can be summarised as so [3]:  Most companies use a mix of 3D CAD and technical drawings - MBD approach eliminates  conflicts between these
Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 9 of 51 Confidential
Copyright © The University of Sheffield / Apr-21 AMRC
Template detail: AMRC
RP Revision 16 (December 2018)
For information about this template contact:  qande@amrc
co
uk   No need for re-creation of technical drawings during development, allowing a more  responsive engineering change process
 Only need to manage one type of file, saving time and server space, as well as allowing a uniform approach to modelling to be devised across a process and/or supply chain
 Can be used to provide a more intuitive display of design and GD&T data, reducing the  likelihood of quality issues arising from the misinterpretation of drawings

 Suited to automating inspection, particularly for when programming CMMs, as geometric  data can be used to program the inspection routine, the design GD&T linked to this and  inspection results appended to the model
 Captures design intent early in the process, allows early addition of GD&T, and can be  used to measure tolerance stacking during the design process
 Ensures that all end users of the model data have the same up-to-date information at all  times, reducing the likelihood of obsolete data being used for any part of the  manufacturing process
2 Limitations Despite MBD having the potential to deliver significant benefits, as detailed in the previous  section, there are also a number of barriers to its implementation

Recurring concerns that  arise across a number of sources are:  A large variety of users, ranging from design teams to technicians to sales teams, may  need access to the model and methods for each of these to access must be carefully  considered so that they deliver functionality while remaining intuitive   Software updates or discrepancies between software in their application of the standards  could lead to incompatibility issues between models
 Other companies in the supply chain may provide or require 2D drawings as part of any  contractual agreement, eliminating some time savings
 Resistance to change from operators with engrained working methods means that effort  needs to be put into staff re-training and familiarisation with the MBD/E process
 A consistent MBD/E framework must be adhered to at all times to ensure that the model  is always properly represented 2
4 Distinction to other ‘Model Based’ approaches MBD and MBE are used as acronyms throughout this report for ‘Model Based Definition’ and  ‘Model Based Enterprise’, as described
However, a number of other acronyms exist within a  similar sphere and are identical or similar to these
The two frequently encountered are:  Model Based Systems Engineering (MBSE) – The use of domain models to exchange  information, in a manner similar to that defined by Model Based Enterprise
 Model Based Design, Model Based Engineering (MBD, MBE) – The systematic use  of computational models to deliver time and cost savings during the design and test  phase of product development
While the above are broad definitions, they are by no means the exclusive definition, and  features of one definition are not necessarily exclusive to that definition
Further, depending on user interpretation and requirements, these terms may be used interchangeably, and more  than one of these approaches may be used at the same time during product development

co
uk  As such, for the avoidance of doubt, for this report ‘MBD’ is an acronym for ‘Model Based  Definition’ and ‘MBE’ is an acronym for ‘Model Based Enterprise’
Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 11 of 51 Confidential
Copyright © The University of Sheffield / Apr-21 AMRC
Template detail: AMRC
RP Revision 16 (December 2018)
For information about this template contact:  qande@amrc
co
uk  3 Current practice While MBD and MBE are not commonplace within the Engineering industry as a whole, they are well-established in some sectors, such aerospace and automotive
Even within these sectors,  however, their adoption is not universal, likely for a number of reasons
This section details  current practice in terms of standards and software
It also provides a review of the current literature around Model Based Definition

MBD formed  the focus of this literature review as it allowed a more focussed approach to the work than  would have been possible with MBE – a literature review featuring MBE would have been too  broad to draw useful conclusions
By specifically investigating MBD, it is likely that any  developments identified would be transferred to the wider manufacturing process, including if  a full MBE approach was utilised

1 Standards A number of standards exist that describe the use of digital methods to represent technical  drawing data, with both the International Organisation for Standardisation (ISO) and the  American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) providing standards
These standards  expand on the established drawing standards (i
e
BS 8888 and ASME Y14
24 etc
) to  dictate the requirements for such drawings to be represented using digital methods
ISO 10303-242 is the standard for product data and exchange in a 3D model-based  manufacturing environment, and defines the STEP 242 file
It has a broad scope, covering most aspects of design and manufacturing, but generally describes how to generate a part such that  it is usable in MBD architectures
This is complemented by standards such as ISO 1101 and  ASME Y14
41, which describe the specification for geometric tolerancing

Further standards have been developed that are specific to given applications, a prime  application being MIL-STD-31000B, which is a document from the US Department of Defence  stating their interpretation of the standards with respect to the generation of technical data  packages
QIF (Quality Information Framework) is an American National Standards Institute (ANSI)  standard for the transmission of PMI, with a focus on the inspection stage of the manufacturing  process
To that end, it is designed to receive CAD in a native format, STEP 242 format or the  QIF MBD format

It then defines rules for the presentation of measurement plans, rules, results, statistics and other parameters relevant to the quality process, with its XML format providing  the flexibility required for storing inspection data

This section is not intended to provide an in-depth overview of these standards as the  standards that apply to given situations can vary, but rather flags their existence as a starting  point for understanding the standards required for the implementation of a manufacturing  process based on MBD
2 Software A number of software packages exist to facilitate the implementation of MBD and MBE
These  are either established CAD packages that include MBD functionality, or third party software  that delivers MBD capabilities using pre-existing software

Key examples include:  Dassault Systemes Catia, Solidworks MBD and 3D Experience  Siemens NX MBD (a plug-in to NX created by Capvidia) Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 12 of 51 Confidential
Copyright © The University of Sheffield / Apr-21 AMRC
Template detail: AMRC
RP Revision 16 (December 2018)
For information about this template contact:  qande@amrc
co
uk   PTC Creo 4
0 Furthermore, some offline programming and other software packages that rely on CAD data  but don’t necessarily generate it (e
g
Mastercam) have been designed to work in an MBD  environment
These programs preserve all data in a model provided that it has been generated in the appropriate format
Most software packages have broadly similar functionality [4]
However, there are some  notable exceptions
For example, most packages output data conforming with the STEP 242  standard, although a few (such as the Siemens NX MBD plug-in discussed above) output in the  ANSI QIF standard
In terms of implementation this standard should deliver comparable results  to STEP 242, but there may be problems related to interoperability where more than one  software package is used
This highlights the necessity for careful consideration of process  requirements prior to the selection of any software to be used for Model Based Definition

While some operate as standalone programs, most are extensions to existing CAD packages,  and the selection of the appropriate MBD software is therefore more likely to be driven by  existing process requirements than individual package functionality

3 Literature review A limited amount of research exists, supported by anecdotal evidence, that the majority of  companies rely wholly or partly on 2D drawings as part of their principle source of design  information [1]

Although only a small sample population was used, the results from this survey indicated that transferring data between the supply chain was an important hindrance in the  uptake of MBD, and a common information model between companies would provide a better  scope for uptake of MBD

A survey by Tech Clarity has shown that interest in the uptake of an MBD is very high [5], with  reasons for its implementation including potential time savings, reduction of paper wastage,  efficiency gains and improvements in the lines of communication with the supply chain
However, a number of blockers were identified with many respondents to the survey stating  that resistance to change was a significant issue, coupled with the requirement for training
This highlights the necessity for accessible and intuitive methods for the implementation of  MBD
Concerns about hardware and the wider supply chain’s adoption of MBD also highlighted  issues
Nevertheless, the majority of respondents that had implemented an MBD approach  reported some benefits to their company
The attitude to an MBD approach within specific aerospace companies is discussed in [3]

While the companies acknowledge the potential benefits of using MBD and the paper clearly indicates that the transition of design data to a single 3D source is possible, doubts remain about the  long-term implications of storing data in the form of 3D models, particularly with regards to  software compatibility and storage issues
A caveat here is that these responses were provided in 2010 - MBD has developed considerably since then, but the concerns in general remain valid for the aerospace industry
Further to this, as MBD is very heavily software driven, the end user of the engineering  drawings needs to have the proper software tools at their disposal and need to be trained to  use it
This leads to an increase of responsibility which can overstrain the users [4]
Further, to  obtain the best value from MBD, designers require proper training in annotation to properly  utilise MBD [6]

A study in 2016 used three typical manufacturing processes to show that the use of MBD could  generate a measurable and significant change in the overall time of the manufacturing  process, with this being less pronounced for the inspection phase [7]
However, this paper  notes that inconsistent PMI can cancel out the benefits gained through the introduction, and it  Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 13 of 51 Confidential
Copyright © The University of Sheffield / Apr-21 AMRC
Template detail: AMRC
RP Revision 16 (December 2018)
For information about this template contact:  qande@amrc
co
uk  therefore suggests that a tool to check product information would encourage wider uptake of  MBD

A tool is demonstrated in [8] that checks the validity of STEP files according to specific  requirements, but it is clear from previous work that the development of more intuitive ‘end  user’ tools may be useful for this purpose
Results from basic trials in [9] show that, when using the standard STEP 242 format, MBD  models can be transferred between different CAD packages while retaining appropriate  accuracy

While this indicates that passing data between CAD users can be software  independent (a feature useful where MBD is implemented in a complex supply chain, for  example), the results also demonstrate that careful selection of parameters is required when  doing so

However, some evidence exists that suggests care must be taken when translating from CAD  to STEP 242, and then to a format suitable for CAM and CMM models, as a complete set of data  is not always transmitted [6]
This should be averted through the use of specialist MBD  software, as discussed in section 3
2, but otherwise indicates that careful validation of the  model is required following any translation

This source also states that the QIF standard may  be more reliable than STEP 242 for transmitting PMI, particularly for the inspection process,  with an overview of QIF provided and its implementation in a metrology workflow discussed in Research also looks at the creation of a framework for incorporating inspection into the MBD  process without the use of QIF, by generating inspection instructions for Coordinate  Measurement Machines (CMMs) [11]

The information from these routines can then be fed into  the model and visualised or used to inform future processes by adjusting future programs  accordingly, or running alternative automated processes depending on the inspection results

MBD has also been shown to be useful during the engineering change process, with a tool  developed in [12] for propagating design changes to a part throughout a whole assembly, and  feeding back the effects of these changes to the user

This tool was shown to reduce the time  taken to analyse the effects of any changes from half a day using traditional engineering  change management methods to approximately two hours for a sample assembly
A successful attempt has been made to extend the MBD methodology to the digital twin to improve the  efficiency of the engineering change process, and to provide more intuitive data presentation 3
1 Literature review summary The benefits of MBD have been demonstrated in specific processes and are recognised by  companies

However, a variety of barriers remain, primarily related to the consistency of data  passed between processes and companies, resistance to change from operators and the  storage requirements over the long term
Some of these issues, such as consistency of data,  are being addressed in the latest literature

Based on the literature review, it is clear that there is little recent data about the current  industrial application of MBD in the United Kingdom, despite the existing information indicating  there is a disconnect between the desire to implement MBD processes and their uptake
By  obtaining usage data, it may be possible to devise a strategy for developing the maturity of  Model Based Definition within industry

uk  4 AMRC partner survey A survey was distributed to AMRC partners to establish the state of Model Based Definition  within the engineering sector

The objectives of this survey were to establish how MBD is  currently defined within industry such that the AMRC can align its research objectives, and to  identify areas where research potential into the implementation of MBD exists
While the  survey was focussed on MBD, many of the questions were designed such that they could be of  use in the implementation of a manufacturing process utilising MBE
1 Survey overview The survey questions were defined in a further AMRC document [14], and a copy of these is  provided in appendix 7

They broadly covered four main areas:  Definition of Model Based Definition  Existing use of CAD and MBD  Perceived advantages of MBD  Perceived disadvantages of MBD The survey consisted of a Google Form and was distributed via social media, partner  engagement emails and via a banner in the Factory 2050 reception area, receiving a total of 18 responses
2 Conclusions The detailed results and conclusions will be reported in a future paper
This report will be up- issued on publication of these results
However, this section provides a brief summary of the  results, the conclusions drawn from the survey, and an overview of useful future work to  enable the implementation of a MBD/E approach
The raw survey responses are not provided  for the sake of brevity, but are available in the appendix, section 7
1 Results overview The survey received 18 responses overall, with 78% of these coming from the United Kingdom,  with 56% of those respondents working in aerospace
44% of respondents were from  companies with less than 250 employees (i
e
SMEs), whilst 39% of responses were from  companies with more than 10,000 employees
Although only 17% of responses came from  medium-sized companies, this may not reflect a lack of engagement, but simply be a reflection of the AMRC’s membership base and wider efforts to engage SMEs
Perceived understanding by the respondents was generally mixed, with engineers in aerospace companies being the most likely to state that they understood MBD
It also appeared that the  level of understanding was consistent, irrespective of the size of the company
Overall, just  over 40% of respondents felt that they understood MBD, while just under 40% felt that they  didn’t, the rest having limited knowledge

Asked about which CAD formats were used, the respondents identified STEP as being the most  common format, implying that the implementation of STEP  242 shouldn’t be too onerous if a  suitable software package was available
However, many respondents noted that they send  and receive design data in differing formats, with a common feature being the receipt of files in the STEP format and their despatch in a native format
This final point has to be given careful  Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 15 of 51 Confidential

However, other key advantages identified included reduction in design time as a result of using CAD as the sole reference, elimination of paper documents from the  shopfloor, streamlined engineering change process and its use as a method for intuitive  distribution of information to the end user

3 Conclusions The survey demonstrated that the respondents viewed the key benefit of MBD being the  provision of a ‘single source of truth’ – that is, a source of up-to-date information for a number  of processes
The was likely to be because this can result in a number of benefits, such as  easier access to information for manufacturing processes and reduced data storage  requirements
The potential quality improvements were also recognised, indicating that quality is a major  driver for MBD implementation
Respondents also saw there being some tangential advantages to MBD, such as facilitating real-time data updates to downstream processes and the intuitive  display of information
MBD appears to be seen as a useful tool for driving process  improvements, and it would be of value to focus further work on the best form for this to take

uk  Respondents were particularly nervous about software capability and user training, with  specific concerns highlighted including lack of functionality and the cost of software
Although  software is available that implements the MBD standards described in section 3
1, it is seen as  expensive and limited in its functionality – representing potential hurdles to for companies to  overcome in their implementation of MBD
User training is an issue across manufacturing, and  it would be beneficial to develop methods to overcome skills gaps in companies looking to  implement MBD

This work may be based around developing more accessible software, novel  frameworks for the implementation of such an approach, improving universality of software  functionality and other similar steps
Further work partially based on these conclusions is discussed in section 6
3 Observations on distribution Having received 18 responses, the survey’s response rate was disappointing when compared  to the size of the AMRC’s membership base

A number of lessons have been learned from the  exercise, and these are detailed below:  Social media had by far the greatest impact on survey responses, with significant jumps  in response when shared via the AMRC’s Facebook, LinkedIn and Twitter accounts
 Presenting MBD and announcing the survey, including the placement of a QR code on the poster, at TechFellows generated a small response
 Distribution in the partner update appeared to have no effect on responses, nor did the  placement of a banner and tablet in Factory 2050 reception
It is likely that social media was effective as it is the information was disseminated to a much  wider audience than just the AMRC’s partner base
Further, although no evidence can be cited  for this, it is reasonable to suggest that those engaging with the AMRC on social media would  be more likely to engage with an online survey

Two rounds of social media posts were  distributed, each generating roughly equivalent increases in response rate – however, it is not  clear if there is a diminishing return on responses as number of rounds increases
The remaining methods may have been ineffective because they did not make the experience  as convenient as possible
During TechFellows, potential respondents may have prioritised  attending presentations and building personal relationships, and as a result have forgotten  about the survey
Similarly, potential respondents may have felt time constrained while waiting in reception and so did not engage with the survey
Anecdotal evidence suggests that some the security policies at some companies prevent the  use of media such as Google Forms
As such, it may not be possible for some respondents to  complete surveys received at work (e
g
partner update being received via work e-mail) and  this may lead to them not responding as, similar to previous highlighted issues, they forget  about the survey

In particular, the hardware consisted of an NI Industrial Smart Camera (type: NI-ISC-1780)  with a resolution of 640 x 480 pixels
An external ring light from Spectrum Illumination (type:  MRL5
5) was mounted around the camera to provide uniform lighting conditions during the  inspection process
The smart camera came with a Power and I/O Accessory that was used to  simplify the power and I/O configurations for controlling the external ring light

The software used is described below:  NI LabVIEW 2019 – for software development   NI MAX 2019 – for configuration of the smart camera (configure on first use)   NI Vision Assistant 2019 – for implementation the inspection routines  Other LabVIEW libraries:  o IMAQ – for image acquisition and processing (vision development module) o MQTT – for connection with main PC via MQTT protocol (third party add-on) NI LabVIEW 2019 was used to program the smart camera and control the external light
The  camera had built-in processor and memory to deploy and run LabVIEW code automatically,  without any intervention
All the inspection routines were implemented using NI Vision  Assistant 2019 and the program was locally deployed into the camera in the form of a real-time application
The communication with the main PC was handled via the MQTT protocol
The application has four running states, which are detailed below:  Connect MQTT: This is the starting state where the camera attempts to connect to the  MQTT broker
If no connection is established, the camera retries to connect every 0
5  seconds until the maximum number of attempts (currently set to 100) is reached
If  unsuccessful, the camera will restart itself
 Read/Write Msg: This is the main state where the camera has already established the  MQTT connection and waits for messages published on its input topic (dev/camera/in)
The connection remains active during this state as the camera checks continuously for  new messages (every 0
2 seconds)
Upon message receipt, the information about the  inspection name is decoded and the corresponding inspection routine is executed
The  result is then sent back to the broker by publishing a message to the camera output topic (dev/camera/out)
If for any reasons the MQTT connection is lost, the program returns to  the “Connect MQTT” state and attempts a new connection with the broker
Any other  errors within this state are captured and sent back to the broker in response to the  inspection request
 Restart Camera: This state programmatically restarts the camera in order to solve  connection issues
After restart, the camera starts the program automatically from the  “Connect MQTT” state
 Stop VI: This state is used to stop the program from running in a safe manner
It is  particularly useful for debugging and when a PC is connected directly to the camera to  make amendments of the code
The above application is set to run at the camera start-up and it remains active while the  camera is turned on
The application stops when connection via the LabVIEW project or NI MAX  is done in order to modify the program code or install new software

During each inspection routine the camera performs the following tasks:  Reads the MQTT message sent from the main PC to decode the inspection name  Sets the exposure time depending on the inspection name Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 22 of 51 Confidential

4 User interface During this project, two main applications were developed, both using C# Windows Forms as  the main interface

One application was a Solidworks plugin that was capable of extracting PMI  information entered into the CAD model, and the other was an application to interface with the  inspection process, allowing the user to select what type of inspection they wished to perform
Screenshots of these applications can be seen in Figure   5
The Solidworks plugin utilised the Solidworks API to extract the Geometric Dimension and  Tolerance (GD&T) and any notes that were attached to the model
The file outputted by the  plugin was a 3D PDF, a PDF that has 3D content such as models embedded within it
An  example of a 3D PDF is provided in Figure   5
The GD&T information was then utilised to  drive a number of operations
Initially, the tolerance values for each of the parts of the model  that were to be inspected were extracted
From these values, it was possible to determine the  appropriate pieces of equipment required to perform each inspection
Figure 5

8 - 3D PDF of the design for the motor retention bracket on which the demonstrator was based After the equipment list was generated, it was then possible to search through the database of  documents relating to all of the pieces of equipment that an organisation has access to, and  the relevant documentation for the specific pieces of equipment, for example Method  Statements and Risk Assessments, could then be attached to the 3D PDF
This enabled the end user to have immediate access to the most up to date version of any documentation they  would require to perform any process on the part, in a convenient location
For example, if the  Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 24 of 51 Confidential

uk  user wanted to check the pre-check procedure for a piece of equipment they would simply  need to open the attachment in the 3D PDF, rather than find the document in the  organisation’s PLM system or refer to a copy located in the working area
It is then also possible to utilise the information regarding the required equipment to drive  Enterprise Resource Planning software
Equipment Driving Licenses are documents that detail  who in the organisation is trained to use which pieces of equipment and to what level
If this  information is stored in a matrix or a central, query-able database, it is possible to determine  which employees are trained to perform the different tasks

Furthermore, if the schedules of  the required employees and the utilisation of the equipment are also accessible, it is possible  to then begin to plan resources, in terms of both employees and equipment, solely based off  the information contained within the CAD model
As well as the relevant equipment documentation, notes attached to the CAD model can also  be extracted from the model, as well as any meta data the designer included in the model file
The notes can contain any information ranging from assembly instructions to COSHH  requirements
This enables a user to also have access to the any and all information regarding  any process of the part will undergo, all contained within a single file

The second application was developed to act as a method of recording the results of both  manual and automated inspection processes, and generating an inspection report from these  results, which was attached to the 3D PDF
This continues the MBD philosophy of having a  single file containing all the relevant information about a part, as each part had an individual  PDF for its instance
Then, as before, if for any reason a person requires information about a  part e
g

what equipment was used to inspect the part, and the results of the inspection, the  user only needs to find one file to access that information rather than multiple files in one  location or possibly multiple files in multiple locations
The application itself operated by identifying the most recently produced 3D PDF in a folder (or  an alternate file can be selected if required)
The user then selected from a list of different  automated inspection processes related to that part
On clicking ‘Automated Inspection’ the  process ran and prompted the user to attach it to the selected 3D PDF
The GD&T information  extracted from the CAD model in the earlier application was used in the inspection process to  determine whether each inspected part had passed or failed the inspection

This method of inspection is advantageous because if, for whatever reason, it is decided that  the required tolerance on the part changes, any 3D PDFs generated from that point on will  carry that information automatically through to the inspection processes with the only user  input required being an update to the GD&T information in the CAD model

5 Backend control Two different methods were used for communicating between the National Instruments camera used for the inspection process and the Kuka Iiwa used to position the camera
Due to the fact  that Kuka’s Sunrise OS cannot communicate via MQTT, TCP/IP was used to send commands to  the cobot

The National Instruments camera already had the required implementation to  receive commands via MQTT, and as an MQTT broker was being implemented for the  integration of the system into a Digital Twin, it was straightforward to use this to communicate  with the camera

The structure of the JSON string being sent to each of the systems was the  same, and was as follows:  "deviceID": "deviceName", "timestamp": "dateTimestamp", "command": { "name": "commandName", "inspection": "inspectionName" "response": { "status": "processStatus", "statusText": "processResponse", "value": "inspectionValue", "image": "imageConvertedTo2DArrayOfPixelValues" This structure allowed the sending and receiving of all required information for any device
The  message sent to the cobot contained the command name ‘move’ and inspection ‘position x’,  with the response returning when the robot had successfully reached that position

The Camera received a message with a command name ‘inspect’ and inspection ‘inspection x’, with a  response value of the measure taken and the resulting image sent to the application in a 2D  array of pixel values
This image was then reconstructed by the application and attached to the 3D PDF along with the inspection report

uk  6 Conclusions and recommendations 6

1 AMRC definition Given the information provided, Model Based Definition can be defined as: “The use of a single 3D model (“single source of truth”), based on a common framework, as the sole design reference for a product” Similarly, Model Based Enterprise can be defined as: “The use of a 3D model as the sole reference for multiple manufacturing processes across a product’s manufacturing cycle”  6
2 Future development The choice of software can be user and application specific
The development of a range of  software solutions that can read files generated through MBD would allow some flexibility to  organisations

For example, a large company could implement different applications for its  design and marketing teams to access the same model, and functionality and presented  information could be customised accordingly
This ties in well with the ethos of the digital thread, in that the provision of information via a  single 3D model allows easy and customisable access to the most up-to-date data

Developing  a reliable system for presenting this to an operator would enable the introduction of digital  work instructions with up-to-date notes and inspection data, as well as information about  defects and the tolerancing state of previous parts in the assembly
Many companies have not engaged with MBD as their sole source of manufacturing  information
As such, some benefits are lost if information is passed between traditional  suppliers and those that have adopted MBD (or vice versa), as time must be spent converting  between 2D and 3D models

One source suggests that companies tend to make their own 3D  models from 2D drawings, even if provided with models alongside the drawings, as the 2D  drawings tend to form the basis of any work contract [1]
As such, the ability to pass a  consistent model between parties could deliver considerable time savings

This highlights one  potential area where a clear best practice for the implementation of MBD across a supply chain could deliver significant time savings, as well as reducing the potential for errors during  drawing translation
The incorporation of such a procedure would, however, need to be tied  into a method for the generation of a common framework such that information is not lost as a  model is passed between users
It is clear that there is little understanding of the use of MBD across a range of industries
While multiple surveys have been conducted to establish how and why MBD is and isn’t used, these  have tended to be limited in scope and with a small population size

While there is considerable research that examines perceived barriers to MBD integration, a better understanding of the  attitude of potential industrial users to the process would provide an indication of where  research should be focused to ensure that companies are able to take maximum advantage of  the potential benefits delivered MBD process
3 Recommendations for short-term development The work suggested previously is an indication of where development work should be broadly  focused
However, some more specific short-term goals are provided below: Document Revision Page IMG036172 Draft 01 28 of 51 Confidential

summary_lines: Capability development for IMG – aiming to establish what Model Based Enterprise (MBE) is, the benefits
it can bring and how it can be used.
To tie in with MACH stand – show off the concept of the ‘digital thread’.
1. Establish a definition for Model Based Definition/Enterprise
2. Find out how it is currently used, how industry perceives it and what are the perceived advantages
3. Identify where the AMRC could usefully contribute to research and development around the subject
4. Produce a demonstrator of an MBD/E implementation for the MACH 2020 trade show
Use of a 3D model as a ‘single-source-of-truth’ for the manufacturing process – linking all processes via a
digital thread to generate improvements in cost and quality.
Two definitions covered by the project:
• MBD (Model Based Definition) – The use of a single 3D model (“single source of truth”), based on a
common framework, as the sole design reference for a product.
• MBE (Model Based Enterprise) – The use of a 3D model as the sole reference for multiple manufacturing
processes across a product’s manufacturing cycle.
• Model Based Systems Engineering (MBSE) – The use of domain models to exchange information, in a
manner similar to that defined by Model Based Enterprise.
• Model Based Design, Model Based Engineering (MBD, MBE) – The systematic use of computational
models to deliver time and cost savings during the design and test phases of product development.
• Only need to manage one type of file, saving time and server
• Can be used to provide a more intuitive display of design
• Suited to automating inspection, particularly for when
• Captures design intent early in the process, allows early
• Ensures that all end users of the model data have the same up-

• Supply chain may provide or require 2D drawings
• Legacy products may make its implementation prohibitive
• Inconsistent MBD/E frameworks lead to inconsistent PMI
• Different users may require different software and

• While the STEP 242 standard provides a framework for the integration of manufacturing data to a 3D

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Document revision history Executive summary The purpose of this document is to conclude the deliverables of the Laing O’Rourke Digitally Assisted Testing work package as part of the wider AMSCI project
The AMRC developed two augmented reality applications to demonstrate and quantify the benefits of augmented reality adoption in assembly, verification, and testing processes
The first application guides an engineer through the continuity testing of an electric panel, which is required as part of factory acceptance testing

The application use a mixture of heads- up-display  (HUD),  virtual  monitors,  and  a  mixed  reality  overlay  to  provide  the  user  with information  of  varying  degrees  of  detail  and  guidance
Using  wireless  communication,  the user’s augmented reality headset communicates with wireless tools and a backend database to fetch the appropriate test procedures and record the results
The second application guides a user through the assembly of a pipe section in preparation for leak testing and stores the test results in a backend database
A monocular HUD provides the user with just-in-time assembly instructions and utilises a wirelessly connected torque wrench to minimise errors and verify assembly
The report discusses the final solutions and compares the potential benefits they afford over the current systems
For each solution, the technology readiness level (TRL) is discussed and suggestions are provided to progress the technology to the next TRL level
