RP Revision 14 (June 2017) 1 Introduction As part of the AMSCI project, Laing O’Rourke wishes to investigate the adoption of augmented reality into existing manufacturing processes at Crown House Technologies
Laing O’Rourke have identified two processes for the pilot scheme to demonstrate and quantify the benefits of augmented reality adoption as part of their assembly, verification, and testing processes
At  Crown  House  Technologies,  a  datasheet  accompanies  each  manufacturing  assembly outlining  the  manufacturing  stages,  current  progress,  and  completion  timestamps
Each assembly  must  undergo  various  factory  acceptance  tests  to  ensure  it  meets  the  relevant industry standards; the paper test results are added to the datasheet

Augmented reality (AR) provides additional context and information to a user’s view through various methods of light projection (the preceding trade study describes AR and the various delivery methods and tools)
For augmented reality to deliver relevant information, data must first be captured, processed, stored, and retrieved
Laing O’Rourke currently do not have a central repository of data for each of the identified processes
Therefore, a backend database for each testing process will be created to simulate a  centralised  repository
The  method  of  data  capture,  processing,  and  storage  for  each database is discussed in the analysis section
Data retrieval and the augmented reality delivery methods are discussed in the hardware and solution sections
Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 7 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017) 2 Electric Panel 2
1 Background Crown House Technologies manufacture the electric control panel for the AMF modular plant room
The modular panel design uses a single schematic to accommodate plant rooms with one to  six  pumps
The electric  panel  houses  both  the  electrical  supply  and the  electronic control for the pumps

Once installed into the plant room module, the panel must be tested and comply with an electrical installation test (BS7671), electrical installation condition report, and a continuity test to ensure the panel has been correctly linked to the external units
The tests occur during the factory acceptance testing, before the module is installed on-site
For the pilot scheme, the continuity test was identified as the first process to adopt augmented reality
Currently, the continuity test requires a qualified and highly skilled engineer with knowledge of the  panel’s  design  and  schematics  to  conduct  the  test  efficiently
Provided  alongside  the schematics is a table describing each cable’s type and dimensions
The engineer uses the schematics  to  identify  each cable  and  the  terminals  of  the  connected  components

Paper documents are used to record test results, with each step completed based on the multimeter readouts and information gathered from the schematics and visual inspections (see Appendix, Error: Reference source not found)
2 Process Analysis There are many inefficiencies inherent to paper based documentation: high risk of loss and damage, document legibility, repetitive data population, and manual data analysis
Recording test results  digitally  can alleviate many of  these issues  [1]
Digital  records  can be stored, shared, and copied across multiple devices and storage mediums, reducing the risk of loss and damage
With digital records, previous records can be retrieved with ease, and data analysis software can provide valuable feedback and anomaly detection
92%  of  the  continuity  test  sheet  can  be  populated  automatically  with  knowledge  of  the schematics, project, and module type
Centralised storage mediums, such as servers, provide many advantages over local storage on individual computers
Servers provide a single point of storage for all users on the same network
This enables collaborative work and real-time access to the latest versions of documents and data
Servers store unstructured data, such as CAD files and other large data structures, but can also store structured data in databases
Project information, module type, and schematic data can be structured and stored in a relational database  [2]
Query languages such as SQL retrieve associated information from a database using value matching
With a relational database, it would be possible to locate all modules, module build status, test data, and associated CAD models for a project

To populate the continuity test sheet with the correct information about an electric panel, the information  regarding  cable  and  component  specifications  and  connections  need  to  be extracted from the schematics into a relational database
Due to the modular nature of the panel, there is a clear relationship between number of pumps and what cables and components are present
With the panel schematics populated in a relational database, we can populate each cable test with its relevant specifications with a database lookup of the panel’s model number

6 Testing To understand the effects of using augmented reality to assist the continuity testing procedure, a series of controlled tests will be conducted
Specifically, the testing procedure will focus on understanding the impact on continuity test completion time and testing accuracy
Two groups, each containing five testers, will perform a continuity test on an electric panel
Group A will conduct the continuity test via the traditional paper-based method, and Group B will conduct the test aided by the augmented reality system
The test sheet used by Group A can be found in Appendix, Continuity Test Report

The electric panel used for the testing will not be connected to any externally components; therefore,  the  continuity  test  will  not  include  an  insulation  resistance  test  or  wire  length measure
A visual check will be conducted as part of the test and requires the tester to check for visible damage or loose connectors
All  cables tests will  be from the EtherCAT terminals
For testing purposes, as there are no external components connected, cables have been crimped together (see Figure 9) to create continuity

1 Test Control To  increase  the  reliability  of  the  results,  certain  variables  of  the  testing  process  will  be controlled: 1

All ten testers will have no prior knowledge of electric panel testing and will receive the same basic instruction of how to read the electric schematics, locate components and cables within a panel, operate a multimeter, and record test results
This will ensure that all testers have the same base level of understanding
The test will consist of the same 20 twisted pairs for all testers in both the paper-based and AR tests
All  20 twisted pairs will  have continuity  and no visible damage,  but this will  not be revealed to the testers
All 40 wires will be correctly labelled with white tags as seen in Figure 9
2 Test Variables The test variables being measured: 1
Time per twisted pair test
For the paper-based tests, this is defined as the moment when the tester first consults the test sheet until the tester finishes recording the results
For the AR testing, it begins when the users starts the next test by saying the voice command “next”
Total  test time
This  is  a  measure of  time taken from the moment the tester first consults the test sheet until the final test results are recorded
Number of skipped test
If a tester misses any of the twisted pair test, this will count as one missed test
Number of mistakes made
A mistake is defined as a tester checking for continuity from the incorrect slot or terminal for the current test, missing a visual check, or missing a continuity test

8 Result Analysis From  the  resulting  data  and  observations  made  during  the  testing  process,  the  use  of augmented reality to assist in the continuity process shows a time saving of 57
7% over using paper schematics and paper-based recording
Augmented reality also showed a decrease in mistakes of 87% and eliminated missed tests for both continuity and visual tests
The comparison of the average standard deviations of a twisted pair test time for both AR (10 seconds) and paper-based (23
5 seconds) shows a significant decrease of 57
It  can be observed in Figure 10 that initial tests took longer with the paper-based method than with AR, which contributes to the larger variance in test time
52% of recorded mistakes for paper-based testing involved incorrect terminal or component testing
83% of incorrect tests were corrected when the tester did not observe continuity and consulted the schematics for confirmation
Visual checks were missed 3% of the time, and 3% of written records contained incorrect information such as wrong component name recorded
The single factor ANOVA result (p-value 0
727) proves there is a statistically significant  difference  between  the  paper-based  and  AR  adjusted  mean  results,  serving  as reasonable grounds for further discussion

1 Background Building  modules  often  require  pipework  to  transport  various  liquids  and  gases  across  a building
The pipework for a module is built in sections, which are assembled together before leak tested
Leak testing is performed through air pressurisation and evaluating pressure decay over time
The normal operating pressure is exceeded during testing to ensure the assembly's integrity, even when over pressurised
A  completed  pipework  can  hold  a  large  volume  of  liquid  or  air  which,  when  pressurised, equates to a dangerous amount  of  potential  energy
For this  reason,  leak testing must be performed in a controlled environment, with the pipework isolated from the operator
If a leak is detected, the operator must enter the test chamber to apply leak detection spray and locate the breach
Entering the test chamber when the pipework is pressurised carries great risk and time locating the leak should be minimised
The likelihood of a leak increases with the size and complexity of an assembly, as leaks can be found in any of the sections or the joints between
Testing smaller pipework sections upon completion reduces the probability of a leak in the final assembly, and narrows the potential sources of a leak to the joints between sections
The risk associated with leak testing small sections of pipework is greatly reduced due to the lower potential energy
For a pipework assembly to be pressurised, endcaps must be attached to all openings
Leaks commonly occur due to the incorrect installation of the endcaps; normally through the omission of a gasket or incorrectly torqued bolts preventing a flush seal
Laing O'Rourke wish to reduce the number of potential leaks when testing the final pipework by having engineers leak test each section upon completion
Laing O'Rourke have identified this process as the second process to adopt augmented reality and digitisation
The proceeding sections analyse the problem and discuss an AR solution
2 Process Analysis The leak testing process can be split into three main tasks: part acquisition, endcap assembly, and leak testing
Part acquisition begins with identifying the quantity and size of the endcaps required to block all open ends of an assembly
Each assembly carries a unique ID number; this can  be  used  to  correctly  identify  the  assembly,  and  querying  a  database  for  the  endcap information
Associating a unique ID with the endcaps and gaskets will provide a method of validation during part selection, further reducing the risk of incorrect assembly
The  second  stage  requires  the  correct  installation  of  the  endcaps  on  the  assembly  in preparation for leak testing
For a correct seal, the flange must be sealed with the correct sized gasket, and tightened with incremental torque in the correct order [9]
Digital work instructions can provide just-in-time information, ensuring an assembly process is completed in the correct order
For a system to provide the correct step at the right time, a feedback loop is required
The unique ID of each endcap can be used to display the correct work instructions, number of bolts,  torque  level,  and  order  of  tightening
Smart  tools  provide  an  automated  method of setting torque based on the work instructions and provide feedback when the target torque has been reached
Endcap installation must be verified before leak testing commences
A leak test instrument Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 22 of 40 Confidential

4 Solution The following section describes the process of completing a leak test through the AR solution on the Vuzix M300
The solution is divided into two stages: endcap assembly and leak testing
A login screen prevents  unauthorised access to the testing application and links  any tests performed to an authorised user
The login process utilises the front facing camera on the AR device to capture a barcode or QR code on an employee’s ID badge
The ID number is used to query the database for a matching employee
1 Endcap Assembly To begin the testing process, the user is prompted to scan the barcode or QR code associated with an assembly
The database is queried for a matching assembly, and returns the endcap and flange dimensions and quantities required to create an airtight seal
Work instructions guide the user through the installation of the endcaps, one at a time
The user is first provided with the name and size of the endcap to be installed
The user then validates an endcap selection by scanning the QR code on the endcap as seen in Figure 13

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Figure 13 Part selection instruction and verification If the correct endcap ID is detected, the work instructions displays a looping animation and text prompt depicting the correct assembly process of the endcap
The gasket, endcap, nuts, bolts, and washers must be assembled and hand tightened, ensuring the gasket stays securely in place (Figure 14)
There is no sensor feedback to validate that the endcap and gasket have been correctly assembled
Instead, the user must manually verify that they have completed this step by pressing ‘Complete’

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Figure 14 The endcap is assembled following the animation on the HUD Once  the  user  indicates  that  they  have  assembled  the  endcap,  a  wireless  connection  is established between the AR device and the Nexo nutrunner
The HUD displays the first target torque and highlights the first bolt to tighten on a top-down view of the endcap (Figure 15)
Bolts are tightened in incremental stages of 30%, 60%, and 100% of target torque
The user is instructed to tighten the bolts at opposing angles to ensure an even distribution of force across the flange  [9]
The highlighted bolt will change to green on the HUD when the target torque value has been reached
If a fault, such as cross-threading, is detected, the nutrunner will stop and the bolt will turn red on the HUD, indicating the bolt must be unthreaded and retightened
Once all  bolts  reach the  same torque,  the  next  incremental  stage  begins
This  process  is repeated until all bolts have reached the target torque
After the final torque values have been reached on all bolts, the assembly process is complete, and the application moves on to the leak testing stage

2 Leak Testing Once the application has iterated through the endcap assembly, the AR device establishes a connection  with  the  leak  test  instrument  via  Telnet
The  user  is  instructed  to  secure  the pressure output hose to the assembly and select the appropriate program
For leak testing, the Sentinel  Blackbelt uses a pressure decay program; the assembly is pressurised to a target pressure and the change in pressure over a period of time is measured
The Telnet connection provides a live feed of data to the AR device, allowing the user to track the testing progress
The final results are saved to the database and displayed on the user’s HUD
The user can now end the testing process and is returned to the beginning to scan the next assembly
5 System Architecture Figure 16 provides a top-level architectural view of the data flow between the components of the AR solution
Similar to the electric panel solution, the AR device acts as a message broker between the smart tool, leak test instrument, database, and user
Raw data from each device is parsed into a user-friendly format before being displayed
Figure 17 depicts the application flow described in the sections above

6 Testing The majority of leaks found during the testing process are located at the endcaps, often due to a missing gasket or unevenly tightened bolts

To understand whether digitising the assembly of pipework sections can reduce the number of leaks, a preliminary test will be conducted to gain a baseline comparison of the current process and the AR guided solution

The following test will therefore analyse of whether augmented reality and smart tools can reduce the number of mistakes made during the assembly process and increase the reliability of the endcap seals
Two groups of three testers will be tasked with preparing an assembly for leak testing
Group A will use the current process, a normal socket set, and paper instructions on how to assemble and tighten each endcap
Group B will use the AR solution and receive assembly and tightening instructions via the Vuzix M300 glasses and Nexo tool
Figure 18 Leak test environment 3
1 Test Control To  increase  the  reliability  of  the  results,  certain  variables  of  the  testing  process  will  be controlled: 1
All six testers will have an understanding of how to assemble an endcap and use the required tools
Each tester will read a three page instruction manual on the process of assembly and the order and stages in which bolts are tightened
The test will consist of the same pipework assembly for both the paper-based and AR tests
The test will be reset for each test with all items placed in the same location as seen in Figure 18
Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 29 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017) 3
2 Test Variables The test variables being measured: 1
Endcap assembly time
The time taken to find the required parts and securely fasten the endcap to the pipework
Total assembly time
The total time taken to secure all endcaps
Number of mistakes
Where a mistake is recorded as missing a gasket or washer, over tightening a bolt, not following the correct tightening sequence, or missing a bolt during a stage of the tightening sequence

8 Analysis An ANOVA analysis of the data does not reveal a significant difference between the traditional and AR completion times, with an average reduction in completion time of  4
There is however, a significant reduction in number of mistakes, with an average of 1 mistake for a 4 Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 30 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017) bolt endcap and an average of 5
5 mistakes for an 8 bolt endcap using traditional tools, and no mistakes for either endcap using the AR application
9 Discussion Research has shown that providing a user with limited, but concise information exactly when required, increases productivity and reduces human error [13]
This augmented reality solution reduces the number of incorrectly assembled endcaps by enforcing incremental tightening, and guiding the user through a tightening sequence
Using a traditional  socket set,  the user is unable to gauge the level of torque being applied and can very easily over or under tighten each bolt during the tightening sequence
This causes a ‘squeezing’ of one side of the endcap as seen in Figure 19, which can cause a pressure leak during testing
Over and under tightened bolts accounted for 38% of mistakes during testing
The potential for under or over tightening has almost been eliminated through the torque control of the Nexo nutrunner, which enforces the tightening stages through a feedback loop
Figure 19 Uneven tightening preventing a correct seal Incorrect tightening sequence accounted for  the majority of mistakes during the traditional method; 52

Showing the status of each bolt’s torque and highlighting the location of the current bolt using a colour coded overview helped testers remember their current progress through  the  tightening  sequence

There  is  however  still  the  possibility  for  mistakes  in  the tightening sequence, as the AR instructions only informs the user of the next bolt, and does not provide any guidance or overlay as seen in the electrical panel testing
This would require an environmental feedback system with the capability to understand the relationship between the bolt and nutrunner locations
5% of  mistakes  during  the  traditional  method  were  due  to  missed components
The AR solution  provides  a  looping  animation  of  the  assembly  process,  providing  hands-free instructions at a glanced while maintaining focus on the assembly
Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 31 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Although there was no significant decrease in total test time when using the AR solution, all users completed the required number of incremental stages for each bolt, whereas some bolts were  missed  during  the  traditional  method
Therefore,  more  tightening  actions  will  have occurred during the AR method, indicating a decrease in per bolt tightening
The user is still required to manually set the program on the leak test instrument; this can be potentially  dangerous  if  variables  are  set  incorrectly
Further  research  is  required  to understand whether these can be programmatically and wirelessly modified
Testing sections of pipework before being assembled into one module will help identify leaks efficiently, and in a safer environment
This will not reduces the risks associate with testing the final assembly, but will reduce the probability of a leak occurring and limit the possible fault locations

Technology Readiness Level All hardware and software used to develop the AR solution are at TRL 9; the hardware is being manufactured and is commercially available, and all software is commercially available with enterprise support
The AR solution is currently considered TRL 4 as all components have only been integrated  and  proven to  provide  a  solution  in  a  test  environment
To  progress  the readiness level of this solution, it needs to be adapted to access Crown House Technologies’ current system to retrieve real assembly data
10 Further Work With the current TRL level of the hardware used for the AR solution, this application could be deployed and used with minimal further work
The system requires further development and exhaustive  software  testing  to  become  a  robust  and  deployable  application
Finally,  the backend database must be merged into Laing O’Rourke’s existing infrastructure to be able to access live assembly data
Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 32 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) 4 Conclusion The solutions developed for both the electric panel and pipework testing have highlighted the potential positive influences augmented reality can provide to increase time efficiency, reduce human error, and provide process verification
An  augmented  overlay  for  the  electric  panel  provides  the  ability  to  highlight  individual components and guide the user’s attention to the terminal locations for each test
This reduces the requirement  for  the  user  to  have  intimate  knowledge  of  the  schematics,  and reduced testing time by almost 58% in the initial testing
A heads-up display provides the user with real- time  feedback  from  the  multimeter  and  database
A  virtual  window  provides  further information about each cable, allowing the user to conduct a full visual inspection
The two- stage  verification  process  ensures  all  cables  are  tested  for  both  continuity  and  a  visual inspection before moving on, greatly reducing the possibility of missed tests
The  current  solution  relies  upon  an  accurate  overlay  to  prevent  incorrect  component highlighting
The degree of  accuracy  required  for  the  continuity  testing  process  is  not  yet robust enough for live industrial use
Research is being conducted at the AMRC to investigate the latest marker and markerless tracking in an effort to increase the reliability of augmented overlay technology
It is recommended that a tablet based adaptation is developed as an initial step towards augmented reality adoption

A tablet based solution would provide the benefit of digital  work  instructions,  relevant  information  retrieval,  but  substitutes  virtual  model highlighting for an augmented overlay (see Figure 11)

Adding  visual  context  to  work  instructions  using  augmented  reality  has  proven  to  reduce assembly time and error in manufacturing processes  [14]; this was the premise of the leak testing augmented reality solution
The Vuzix M300 monocular  device provides digital  work instructions  to  assist  in the  correct  assembly sequence of  endcaps  in  preparation  for  leak testing
A smart tool enforces incremental tightening of the bolts to improve the chances of a tight seal
However, without verification of which bolt is being tightened, the system cannot completely eliminate human error
This could be resolved with the implementation of a visual feedback loop

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Document revision history Executive summary The purpose of this document is to conclude the deliverables of the Laing O’Rourke Digitally Assisted Testing work package as part of the wider AMSCI project
The AMRC developed two augmented reality applications to demonstrate and quantify the benefits of augmented reality adoption in assembly, verification, and testing processes
The first application guides an engineer through the continuity testing of an electric panel, which is required as part of factory acceptance testing

The application use a mixture of heads- up-display  (HUD),  virtual  monitors,  and  a  mixed  reality  overlay  to  provide  the  user  with information  of  varying  degrees  of  detail  and  guidance
Using  wireless  communication,  the user’s augmented reality headset communicates with wireless tools and a backend database to fetch the appropriate test procedures and record the results
The second application guides a user through the assembly of a pipe section in preparation for leak testing and stores the test results in a backend database
A monocular HUD provides the user with just-in-time assembly instructions and utilises a wirelessly connected torque wrench to minimise errors and verify assembly
The report discusses the final solutions and compares the potential benefits they afford over the current systems
For each solution, the technology readiness level (TRL) is discussed and suggestions are provided to progress the technology to the next TRL level

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) 1 Introduction As part of the AMSCI project, Laing O’Rourke wishes to investigate the adoption of augmented reality into existing manufacturing processes at Crown House Technologies
Laing O’Rourke have identified two processes for the pilot scheme to demonstrate and quantify the benefits of augmented reality adoption as part of their assembly, verification, and testing processes
At  Crown  House  Technologies,  a  datasheet  accompanies  each  manufacturing  assembly outlining  the  manufacturing  stages,  current  progress,  and  completion  timestamps
Each assembly  must  undergo  various  factory  acceptance  tests  to  ensure  it  meets  the  relevant industry standards; the paper test results are added to the datasheet

Augmented reality (AR) provides additional context and information to a user’s view through various methods of light projection (the preceding trade study describes AR and the various delivery methods and tools)
For augmented reality to deliver relevant information, data must first be captured, processed, stored, and retrieved
Laing O’Rourke currently do not have a central repository of data for each of the identified processes
Therefore, a backend database for each testing process will be created to simulate a  centralised  repository
The  method  of  data  capture,  processing,  and  storage  for  each database is discussed in the analysis section
Data retrieval and the augmented reality delivery methods are discussed in the hardware and solution sections
Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 7 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017) 2 Electric Panel 2
1 Background Crown House Technologies manufacture the electric control panel for the AMF modular plant room
The modular panel design uses a single schematic to accommodate plant rooms with one to  six  pumps
The electric  panel  houses  both  the  electrical  supply  and the  electronic control for the pumps

Once installed into the plant room module, the panel must be tested and comply with an electrical installation test (BS7671), electrical installation condition report, and a continuity test to ensure the panel has been correctly linked to the external units
The tests occur during the factory acceptance testing, before the module is installed on-site
For the pilot scheme, the continuity test was identified as the first process to adopt augmented reality
Currently, the continuity test requires a qualified and highly skilled engineer with knowledge of the  panel’s  design  and  schematics  to  conduct  the  test  efficiently
Provided  alongside  the schematics is a table describing each cable’s type and dimensions
The engineer uses the schematics  to  identify  each cable  and  the  terminals  of  the  connected  components

Paper documents are used to record test results, with each step completed based on the multimeter readouts and information gathered from the schematics and visual inspections (see Appendix, Error: Reference source not found)
2 Process Analysis There are many inefficiencies inherent to paper based documentation: high risk of loss and damage, document legibility, repetitive data population, and manual data analysis
Recording test results  digitally  can alleviate many of  these issues  [1]
Digital  records  can be stored, shared, and copied across multiple devices and storage mediums, reducing the risk of loss and damage
With digital records, previous records can be retrieved with ease, and data analysis software can provide valuable feedback and anomaly detection
92%  of  the  continuity  test  sheet  can  be  populated  automatically  with  knowledge  of  the schematics, project, and module type
Centralised storage mediums, such as servers, provide many advantages over local storage on individual computers
Servers provide a single point of storage for all users on the same network
This enables collaborative work and real-time access to the latest versions of documents and data
Servers store unstructured data, such as CAD files and other large data structures, but can also store structured data in databases
Project information, module type, and schematic data can be structured and stored in a relational database  [2]
Query languages such as SQL retrieve associated information from a database using value matching
With a relational database, it would be possible to locate all modules, module build status, test data, and associated CAD models for a project

To populate the continuity test sheet with the correct information about an electric panel, the information  regarding  cable  and  component  specifications  and  connections  need  to  be extracted from the schematics into a relational database
Due to the modular nature of the panel, there is a clear relationship between number of pumps and what cables and components are present
With the panel schematics populated in a relational database, we can populate each cable test with its relevant specifications with a database lookup of the panel’s model number
Wirelessly connected tools send information about its current state and sensor feedback data to any connected and listening devices
The receiving device can use and manipulate that data Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 8 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017) as  required
Some connected tools  can also receive  input,  allowing them to be  controlled externally
A wirelessly connected multimeter would be able to provide continuity results back to a listening device, which can format and store the feedback data in a database
Augmented reality requires information about the user’s physical  surroundings to provide a contextual overlay
This is captured through various sensors such as monocular and binocular cameras, IR depth cameras, and inertial measurement units (IMU)
Post processing on sensor feedback helps to locate the user and identify objects in view

With a virtual model of an object or environment and an understanding of the user’s location, it is possible to align the digital world to the physical world, creating an overlay as seen in Error: Reference source not found
An augmented overlay allows for object highlighting as seen in Figure 6
Currently no CAD models of the electric panel exist, but one can be reverse engineered using a laser scanner and modelling software
Most manufacturers of the components used inside the panel have freely available CAD models

A digital model of the electric panel was created in 3DS Max by measuring the external dimensions of the panel, and overlaying a laser scan of the physical panel to precisely place the CAD models of the components, as seen in Figure 1
Figure 1 High-density laser scan used as a guide for reverse engineering a CAD model 2
3 Hardware and Software This section discusses the hardware and software used in the creation of the electric panel AR application
1 Development Software The AR application was developed using the Unity game development environment [3]
Unity supports  deployment  to  a  wide  range  of  devices  including  Universal  Windows  Platform, Android, and iOS
With a wide customer base, there are many plugins available and extensive documentation
With  such  a  wide  following,  most  AR  platforms  provide  a  Unity  plugin, providing the basic functionality for starting an AR application
Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 9 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017) The application code was written, debugged, and compiled using Microsoft Visual Studio 2017 [4]
Visual Studio includes the latest version of
NET, used by the Microsoft HoloLens operating system, and enables quick deployment and real-time debugging wirelessly for the HoloLens
2 Database The database used for this solution was a Microsoft SQL Server database  [5] running on a Windows  Server  2012  machine
For  security,  all  queries  are  required  to  go  through  an application programming interface (API) form a registered device with an API key, and user credentials
The API also checks incoming queries for correct syntax to eliminate SQL injection attacks
There are also various user privilege levels, restricting functionality to only what is required for the user’s role
3 Augmented Reality and Mixed Reality The solution will guide the user with three types of AR: heads-up-display, virtual window, and an augmented overlay

The virtual window and augmented overlay are considered as ‘mixed reality’;  a subset of augmented reality which uses closed loop feedback about the physical environment and a devices movement to anchor the virtual objects in the physical world [6]
Accurate  head  and  environment  tracking are  essential  to  provide  the  overlay  as components in the electric panel are very close  together  and  as  narrow  as  10mm
The  Microsoft  HoloLens  was  selected  as the AR delivery device for this solution due to its  unique spatial  mapping capabilities and multiple input methods
The HoloLens uses an IMU and four cameras to track the user’s environment and accurately tracks head  movement
The  HoloLens  is controlled through gaze, voice, and hand gestures
The standard HoloLens gestures will be used to navigate the application; a list  of  the gestures and how to perform them can be found at [7]
The AR application uses PTC’s Vuforia plugin for Unity to initialise and orientate
A personalised VuMarks for Laing O’Rourke, created in Adobe Illustrator, serves as the point of origin to align the digital model in the real world, and to uniquely identify the electric panel
4 Multimeter The trade study found that most wirelessly connected multimeters on the market require the use of a proprietary storage solution, normally storing readouts on a manufacturer’s server
To provide real-time feedback a direct wireless connection is required

Redfish provide the iDVM- 510  multimeter  with  documentation  for  the  Bluetooth-LE  communication  characteristics, enabling access and transfer of data between the meter and other Bluetooth-LE devices
The Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 10 of 40 Confidential
© 2021 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Figure 2 Microsoft HoloLens sensor arrayFigure 3 Microsoft HoloLens sensor array AR solution uses the iDVM-510 to connect to the HoloLens via Bluetooth-LE
4 Solution The following section explains  the  process  of  performing a continuity  test  through the  AR solution with the Microsoft  HoloLens
Navigating  the  application  is  accomplished through a virtual window
When the application is loaded, a virtual window loads directly in front of the user at a distance of one metre

A navigation bar is always located at the top of the window and displays a descriptive name for the current view, and houses controls to move the window or navigate between screens using the air tap gesture
1 Login Upon launching the application, the user is presented with a login screen
The user must tap on an input field to bring up the virtual QWERTY keyboard
This was designed to be a familiar experience for users that have previously used touch screen devices such as tablets our mobile phones

6 Testing To understand the effects of using augmented reality to assist the continuity testing procedure, a series of controlled tests will be conducted
Specifically, the testing procedure will focus on understanding the impact on continuity test completion time and testing accuracy
Two groups, each containing five testers, will perform a continuity test on an electric panel

8 Result Analysis From  the  resulting  data  and  observations  made  during  the  testing  process,  the  use  of augmented reality to assist in the continuity process shows a time saving of 57
7% over using paper schematics and paper-based recording
Augmented reality also showed a decrease in mistakes of 87% and eliminated missed tests for both continuity and visual tests
The comparison of the average standard deviations of a twisted pair test time for both AR (10 seconds) and paper-based (23
5 seconds) shows a significant decrease of 57
It  can be observed in Figure 10 that initial tests took longer with the paper-based method than with AR, which contributes to the larger variance in test time
52% of recorded mistakes for paper-based testing involved incorrect terminal or component testing
83% of incorrect tests were corrected when the tester did not observe continuity and consulted the schematics for confirmation
Visual checks were missed 3% of the time, and 3% of written records contained incorrect information such as wrong component name recorded
The single factor ANOVA result (p-value 0
727) proves there is a statistically significant  difference  between  the  paper-based  and  AR  adjusted  mean  results,  serving  as reasonable grounds for further discussion

The solution relies heavily on the accuracy of the augmented overlay
Misalignment of more than 5mm introduces uncertainty in determining a highlighted slot
Manual adjustments of the overlay  ensures  the  alignment  is  within  tolerance,  but  relies  upon  user  judgment
Once alignment  is  complete,  the  HoloLens’  SLAM  capabilities  prevented  the  alignment  from exceeding the 5mm tolerance throughout the testing process

It is recommended that the user allows time for the HoloLens to generate a complete spatial  map of the electric panel and surrounding area prior to loading the application,  as partial  spatial  maps tend to introduce stuttered movements of the overlay during HoloLens motion
Movement of the electric panel during  testing  can  currently  causes  misalignment,  which  is  not  automatically  corrected
Continuous tracking was trialled but rejected, after results proved to be less accurate without the ability to fine-tune the overlay
A potential solution would be to use a multi marker based tracking solution or edge detection to improve the accuracy of automatic alignment
The current login process was designed to add a level of security by requiring a username and password
Using a virtual keyboard requires both gaze control to focus on a key, and an air tap gesture  to select  the key
This  has  proven to be imprecise and slow if  the user does not perform the correct gesture or moves during the gesture
Using the front facing camera to detect an identification badge, as used in the Pipe Assembly Leak Test solution (see  2
1), would be a more efficient solution and eliminate all user input
The barcode on an identification badge  can  easily  be  copied,  which  could  present  a  serious  security  unless  a  secondary verification process was utilised
The health and safety implications of using wearable technology over an extended period of time is currently unknown

1 Background Building  modules  often  require  pipework  to  transport  various  liquids  and  gases  across  a building
The pipework for a module is built in sections, which are assembled together before leak tested
Leak testing is performed through air pressurisation and evaluating pressure decay over time
The normal operating pressure is exceeded during testing to ensure the assembly's integrity, even when over pressurised
A  completed  pipework  can  hold  a  large  volume  of  liquid  or  air  which,  when  pressurised, equates to a dangerous amount  of  potential  energy
For this  reason,  leak testing must be performed in a controlled environment, with the pipework isolated from the operator
If a leak is detected, the operator must enter the test chamber to apply leak detection spray and locate the breach
Entering the test chamber when the pipework is pressurised carries great risk and time locating the leak should be minimised
The likelihood of a leak increases with the size and complexity of an assembly, as leaks can be found in any of the sections or the joints between
Testing smaller pipework sections upon completion reduces the probability of a leak in the final assembly, and narrows the potential sources of a leak to the joints between sections
The risk associated with leak testing small sections of pipework is greatly reduced due to the lower potential energy
For a pipework assembly to be pressurised, endcaps must be attached to all openings
Leaks commonly occur due to the incorrect installation of the endcaps; normally through the omission of a gasket or incorrectly torqued bolts preventing a flush seal
Laing O'Rourke wish to reduce the number of potential leaks when testing the final pipework by having engineers leak test each section upon completion
Laing O'Rourke have identified this process as the second process to adopt augmented reality and digitisation
The proceeding sections analyse the problem and discuss an AR solution
2 Process Analysis The leak testing process can be split into three main tasks: part acquisition, endcap assembly, and leak testing
Part acquisition begins with identifying the quantity and size of the endcaps required to block all open ends of an assembly
Each assembly carries a unique ID number; this can  be  used  to  correctly  identify  the  assembly,  and  querying  a  database  for  the  endcap information
Associating a unique ID with the endcaps and gaskets will provide a method of validation during part selection, further reducing the risk of incorrect assembly
The  second  stage  requires  the  correct  installation  of  the  endcaps  on  the  assembly  in preparation for leak testing
For a correct seal, the flange must be sealed with the correct sized gasket, and tightened with incremental torque in the correct order [9]
Digital work instructions can provide just-in-time information, ensuring an assembly process is completed in the correct order
For a system to provide the correct step at the right time, a feedback loop is required
The unique ID of each endcap can be used to display the correct work instructions, number of bolts,  torque  level,  and  order  of  tightening
Smart  tools  provide  an  automated  method of setting torque based on the work instructions and provide feedback when the target torque has been reached
Endcap installation must be verified before leak testing commences
A leak test instrument Document No State Revision Page IMG007886 Draft 1 22 of 40 Confidential

4 Solution The following section describes the process of completing a leak test through the AR solution on the Vuzix M300
The solution is divided into two stages: endcap assembly and leak testing
A login screen prevents  unauthorised access to the testing application and links  any tests performed to an authorised user
The login process utilises the front facing camera on the AR device to capture a barcode or QR code on an employee’s ID badge
The ID number is used to query the database for a matching employee
1 Endcap Assembly To begin the testing process, the user is prompted to scan the barcode or QR code associated with an assembly
The database is queried for a matching assembly, and returns the endcap and flange dimensions and quantities required to create an airtight seal
Work instructions guide the user through the installation of the endcaps, one at a time
The user is first provided with the name and size of the endcap to be installed
The user then validates an endcap selection by scanning the QR code on the endcap as seen in Figure 13

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Figure 13 Part selection instruction and verification If the correct endcap ID is detected, the work instructions displays a looping animation and text prompt depicting the correct assembly process of the endcap
The gasket, endcap, nuts, bolts, and washers must be assembled and hand tightened, ensuring the gasket stays securely in place (Figure 14)
There is no sensor feedback to validate that the endcap and gasket have been correctly assembled
Instead, the user must manually verify that they have completed this step by pressing ‘Complete’

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Figure 14 The endcap is assembled following the animation on the HUD Once  the  user  indicates  that  they  have  assembled  the  endcap,  a  wireless  connection  is established between the AR device and the Nexo nutrunner
The HUD displays the first target torque and highlights the first bolt to tighten on a top-down view of the endcap (Figure 15)
Bolts are tightened in incremental stages of 30%, 60%, and 100% of target torque
The user is instructed to tighten the bolts at opposing angles to ensure an even distribution of force across the flange  [9]
The highlighted bolt will change to green on the HUD when the target torque value has been reached
If a fault, such as cross-threading, is detected, the nutrunner will stop and the bolt will turn red on the HUD, indicating the bolt must be unthreaded and retightened
Once all  bolts  reach the  same torque,  the  next  incremental  stage  begins
This  process  is repeated until all bolts have reached the target torque
After the final torque values have been reached on all bolts, the assembly process is complete, and the application moves on to the leak testing stage

The  user  is  instructed  to  secure  the pressure output hose to the assembly and select the appropriate program

9 Discussion Research has shown that providing a user with limited, but concise information exactly when required, increases productivity and reduces human error [13]
This augmented reality solution reduces the number of incorrectly assembled endcaps by enforcing incremental tightening, and guiding the user through a tightening sequence
Using a traditional  socket set,  the user is unable to gauge the level of torque being applied and can very easily over or under tighten each bolt during the tightening sequence
This causes a ‘squeezing’ of one side of the endcap as seen in Figure 19, which can cause a pressure leak during testing
Over and under tightened bolts accounted for 38% of mistakes during testing
The potential for under or over tightening has almost been eliminated through the torque control of the Nexo nutrunner, which enforces the tightening stages through a feedback loop
Figure 19 Uneven tightening preventing a correct seal Incorrect tightening sequence accounted for  the majority of mistakes during the traditional method; 52

Showing the status of each bolt’s torque and highlighting the location of the current bolt using a colour coded overview helped testers remember their current progress through  the  tightening  sequence

There  is  however  still  the  possibility  for  mistakes  in  the tightening sequence, as the AR instructions only informs the user of the next bolt, and does not provide any guidance or overlay as seen in the electrical panel testing
This would require an environmental feedback system with the capability to understand the relationship between the bolt and nutrunner locations
5% of  mistakes  during  the  traditional  method  were  due  to  missed components
The AR solution  provides  a  looping  animation  of  the  assembly  process,  providing  hands-free instructions at a glanced while maintaining focus on the assembly

Template – AMRC

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) Although there was no significant decrease in total test time when using the AR solution, all users completed the required number of incremental stages for each bolt, whereas some bolts were  missed  during  the  traditional  method
Therefore,  more  tightening  actions  will  have occurred during the AR method, indicating a decrease in per bolt tightening
The user is still required to manually set the program on the leak test instrument; this can be potentially  dangerous  if  variables  are  set  incorrectly
Further  research  is  required  to understand whether these can be programmatically and wirelessly modified
Testing sections of pipework before being assembled into one module will help identify leaks efficiently, and in a safer environment
This will not reduces the risks associate with testing the final assembly, but will reduce the probability of a leak occurring and limit the possible fault locations

Technology Readiness Level All hardware and software used to develop the AR solution are at TRL 9; the hardware is being manufactured and is commercially available, and all software is commercially available with enterprise support
The AR solution is currently considered TRL 4 as all components have only been integrated  and  proven to  provide  a  solution  in  a  test  environment
To  progress  the readiness level of this solution, it needs to be adapted to access Crown House Technologies’ current system to retrieve real assembly data
10 Further Work With the current TRL level of the hardware used for the AR solution, this application could be deployed and used with minimal further work
The system requires further development and exhaustive  software  testing  to  become  a  robust  and  deployable  application
Finally,  the backend database must be merged into Laing O’Rourke’s existing infrastructure to be able to access live assembly data

RP Revision 14 (June 2017) 4 Conclusion The solutions developed for both the electric panel and pipework testing have highlighted the potential positive influences augmented reality can provide to increase time efficiency, reduce human error, and provide process verification
An  augmented  overlay  for  the  electric  panel  provides  the  ability  to  highlight  individual components and guide the user’s attention to the terminal locations for each test
This reduces the requirement  for  the  user  to  have  intimate  knowledge  of  the  schematics,  and reduced testing time by almost 58% in the initial testing
A heads-up display provides the user with real- time  feedback  from  the  multimeter  and  database
A  virtual  window  provides  further information about each cable, allowing the user to conduct a full visual inspection
The two- stage  verification  process  ensures  all  cables  are  tested  for  both  continuity  and  a  visual inspection before moving on, greatly reducing the possibility of missed tests
The  current  solution  relies  upon  an  accurate  overlay  to  prevent  incorrect  component highlighting
The degree of  accuracy  required  for  the  continuity  testing  process  is  not  yet robust enough for live industrial use
Research is being conducted at the AMRC to investigate the latest marker and markerless tracking in an effort to increase the reliability of augmented overlay technology
It is recommended that a tablet based adaptation is developed as an initial step towards augmented reality adoption

A tablet based solution would provide the benefit of digital  work  instructions,  relevant  information  retrieval,  but  substitutes  virtual  model highlighting for an augmented overlay (see Figure 11)

Adding  visual  context  to  work  instructions  using  augmented  reality  has  proven  to  reduce assembly time and error in manufacturing processes  [14]; this was the premise of the leak testing augmented reality solution
The Vuzix M300 monocular  device provides digital  work instructions  to  assist  in the  correct  assembly sequence of  endcaps  in  preparation  for  leak testing
A smart tool enforces incremental tightening of the bolts to improve the chances of a tight seal
However, without verification of which bolt is being tightened, the system cannot completely eliminate human error
This could be resolved with the implementation of a visual feedback loop

Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 5 of 27  4 Introduction   Vision systems are used extensively in automation as a flexible form of metrology  and sensing, allowing a system to have a view of work akin to a human’s view on a  task
However solutions are often challenging to implement for several reasons, such  as variations in lighting, reflective nature of surfaces, and limitations placed by  camera accuracy and calibration

To combat this, industrial vision software often comes with advanced built-in features  that allow a relatively inexperienced user to filter difficult camera feeds and images to  reliably make out features and perform a task (i
e
guide a robot, measure a part)
This software is often designed to be used in tandem with industrial specification  cameras which are guaranteed to perform as specified and give a usable image for  inspecting
These industrial systems provide a proven and reliable base, but at a high cost
For  research projects, the cost of testing if a vision system is suitable for a purpose can  be prohibitively high

Outside of vision systems, camera technology for general consumers has been  driven particularly rapidly to the point where many modern devices have high-spec  cameras with  high pixel counts developed at a low cost
This has led to a great drive  in improving the quality and cost of digital camera systems, leading to high quality  and very low cost cameras being widely available
Combined with this, many open- source vision solutions have been developed by programmers over recent years
Open-source software is created under open-source licenses online by any  developers who want to take part
This makes it free to use, and provides the entire  code base for modification if needed

The purpose of this project was to determine if the recent drive in camera technology  paired with stable versions of open-source vision software could provide a decent  testing bed for vision systems and the find a way to grade the quality of these  systems against each other and the proven industrial equivalents
Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 6 of 27  5 Selection of Systems  There is a wide range of open source and commercial vision systems available on  the market
Due to limited time and to ensure the project was kept in budget, a  limited number of open-source software packages and commercial-off-the-shelf  hardware had to be picked to look at in detail
To  down select from the wider range  of choices, a review was conducted of available solutions
The visible features, pros,  and cons were weighed up to decide what would represent the most useful solution  for the project
1 Review of Open-source Software  Firstly, an overall search was undertaken to see what software could be found online  and what features were available, with the results collated for this review

During this search, it became obvious that open-source solutions weren’t available  fully-featured as a software package and user interface akin to the industrial  equivalents the AMRC had used previously
Instead, most open-source vision code  was available in the form of a programming library
This means that rather than a  fixed program with a pre-made interface, they consist of add-ons for a programming  language

These add-ons aim to provide the complex functions of vision software  without the programming effort; instead allowing for a simpler line of code in your  chosen language to call a library function that does the complex work load and  returns the results in a set format for your program to use
Several libraries were found at varying degrees of functionality and completeness
These were narrowed down into a set of options that were still supported by  developers and could fit the majority of our needs for a vision package in the project
Once this sub-set of libraries had been decided upon, they were looked at in greater  detail to ascertain which ones would be worth devoting programming time to using  fully in experimentation
The available literature on each was looked at and the  resulting expected capacity of the library was recorded
The results of this are  displayed in Table 1 and Table 2 below
(The industrial solutions available to the  AMRC at the time have been included for comparison purposes)

Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 8 of 27  Regarding the feature criteria looked at it was assumed that, even if it was possible  to make the library perform the listed feature though programming, if it wasn’t a core  components of the library to begin with it would be marked as not available
This was  in order to provide a boundary between obtained software and AMRC programmed  work

1 Distinction between library and software  As mentioned earlier, software libraries differ from complete programs in that they aid  the programming of a solution, rather than providing a packaged, out-of-the box,  solution
The issue this created was how far we were willing to go programming each  system
At a basic level, any programming language should be capable of performing  any vision work without a library, by building a new vision application from scratch

Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 9 of 27  However this would require a large amount of programming time and  skill, as well as  full verification of the software’s performance afterwards
This was deemed an  inefficient use of time and cost,   therefore pre-programmed packages  were used  instead

In the case of libraries, they provide a halfway solution between fully-programmed  solutions and existing software: programming is required but it is made easier with  existing functions that can be easily called to perform vision tasks
Because of this,  the divide between programming done by the AMRC and features included in the  library was vague
For this reason when evaluating programming libraries, if the task  appeared to require programming work beyond function calls and parameters, it was  considered to not have that function
When programming, limits were also applied on  the time spend implementing features, so as to ensure no library had extra  development over the others

2 Final Open Source Software Choice  After reviewing the shortlist of systems, including programming with a selection of  them briefly to confirm the basic functionality claims, it was decided that there was  time to develop full vision system applications with two libraries
The chosen systems  were:   AForge
NET (version 2
3)   OpenCV (version 2
4 Windows/Linux)  These were both chosen due to the maturity of development and range of features  available
They also complemented each other reasonably, as AForge
NET was a
NET based C# library (a Microsoft language used extensively at the AMRC in  previous projects) and tied into the Visual Studio IDE, while OpenCV was C++  based

C++ is one of the most widely used and efficient modern “high-level”  programming language available, and the library was not locked to Windows  machines, but also functioned in Linux distributions (among others)
2 Industrial Software  In order to offer a baseline for comparison to, industrial solutions that the AMRC were  familiar with were included in the experiments
The two solutions selected were:   Cognex   Scorpion Vision  Cognex is a set of vision solutions developed by the Cognex Corporation
They  consist of a range of industrial cameras with built-in micro-processors and bespoke  software to setup the inspections these cameras are to carry out
While the hardware  is often more expensive than an equivalent camera, the advantage of this setup is  that the micro-processor on the camera can carry out the inspection
This removes  the need for more expensive and potentially unreliable computer hardware and any  attached wiring
The range of software is also simple to use and user friendly,  providing a GUI for setting up inspections and tweaking the parameters
There are different cameras within the Cognex range for different applications
For  this project, the AMRC decided on an Intellect Machine Vision camera, using an  Intellect 554 camera (covered below in 5
1 Commercial Cameras) and the Intellect  v1
1 software
This software uses a set of graphical tools that are dropped onto the  Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 10 of 27  screen to create inspections, and some basic scripting and parameter editing to set  the details of these inspections
This setup is them loaded onto the camera micro- processor, which them runs the inspections when called over TCP/IP, returning the  results in a string format defined by the user
Scorpion Vision is industrial vision software only, that works on any standard or  industrial camera
It runs on Windows as a software package, and uses drag-and- drop elements and scripting similar to Cognex to offer user-friendly setup of complex  vision tasks
Advanced scripting is done in the Python programming language
Both of these systems offer guaranteed performance and reliability within set  boundaries for inspections they carry out, as well as easy-to-understand interfaces  and controls

This means they are very suitable for rapid deployment in industrial  environments, since they have existing performance guarantees and can be setup by  engineers rather than requiring a large amount of programming expertise
3 Hardware Selection  Use of vision systems has been driven by the development of digital photo-electric  light sensors
These take in light, concentrated onto a small chip through a lens, and  convert it into electrons in a photo-electric cell on the chip
The chips vary in  manufacturing techniques, leading to two main sensor types; complementary metal- oxide semiconductor (CMOS) and charge-coupled device (CCD)
They work in the  same general way, with CMOS taking less power and producing higher resolution  images, but with more noise and therefore lower image quality than CCD
A large array of these photo-electric cells on the chip provides each pixel of the  image
The electron “level” can then be converted into a value, and these pixel  values and positions are put together to create a whole digital image
All the vision  systems looked at work on using same technology
As with the software selection, the hardware was selected to cover both Commercial- off-the-Shelf (CotS) cameras and industrial cameras for a benchmark to compare  them to
1 Commercial Cameras  For the CotS camera system, we looked specifically at webcams
Webcams are low- cost computer cameras, typically for video conferencing purposes
They are typically  small and require very low power to run

Internally, they are similar to many other  low-cost digital cameras, although they usually lack complex optical lensing to reduce  cost, and are built to stream video images as easily as high-resolution stills
Two cameras were selected: the Microsoft LifeCam Studio and the Trust Spotlight
These represented the top-end and lower-end of typical home and office digital  webcams at the time of the project
These are shown in Table 3 below:  Document No

2 Industrial Cameras  Since the Cognex Intellect software (detailed in Table 4) is tied to a camera, it was  necessary to use a Cognex Intellect DVT 554 camera
It is the top of the Intellect  DVT range along with the identical resolution DVT554C (colour version of the  camera), although this is no longer Cognex’s newest range of camera
This camera contains a micro-processor that can process the inspection data  internally in real-time and transmit it, removing the need for an attached PC once it is  commissioned
However, this means it can only be used as a Cognex camera, and  not by any other software
The Unibrain Fire-1 630b camera is a small industrial camera that works over  FireWire
It is relatively expensive, but it has internal processing capabilities that  enable a high repeatability of performance
It is mid-way in the Unibrain range of  “ultra-compact” industrial cameras

Camera Cost Sensor Resolution  (stills)  Resolution/FPS  (video)  Data  transfer  method  Focus Colour  Unibrain  Fire-i  630b  (+lens)  (circa  CCD 1024 x 768 N/A (software  dependent)  FireWire Manual  (lens  dependent)  No  Cognex  Intellect  (+lens)  (circa  CCD 1280x1024 N/A (Live video  function not  used for  inspection)  TCP/IP  (processed  on-board)  Manual  (lens  dependent)  No  Table 4: Industrial camera comparison   Both industrial cameras use the older, more proven CCD technology for sensors
They run at lower resolutions than the CMOS based CotS cameras, but the CCD  sensor produces lower noise images
They also both feature proper lens mounts,  and require a lens to be specified and fitted before any measurement tasks

The biggest differences are that the Cognex camera performs inspections on-board  and communicates results over TCP/IP, while the Unibrain uses the FireWire  standard to transmit pictures to the computer
For this reason, the Cognex camera  cannot be used with other software packages
Document No
