Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 13 of 27  Figure 3: Cognex Intellect DVT 554  Figure 4: Unibrain Fire-i 630b  6 Setup  6
1 Testing Criteria  In order to test the chosen systems a testing criteria had to be developed to enable a  fair comparison of each
First, a list of features that would be useful was drafted
This  was compiled through informal meetings with IMG and partner members, discussing  what vision systems are used for and what they ideally could be used for in the  future
From these criteria, the AMRC proceeded to develop a set of tests that would give a  measurable result
From this, a comparison of the performance of each system in  given categories could be performed
For tests such as hole finding a metric can be easily determined since the results are  numerical
However, some of the tests listed are more difficult to get a measurable  Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 14 of 27  metric for, such as ease-of-use and scripting potential
For these an overview of the  AMRC’s experience was recorded in writing and a simple scoring system was  applied, but they weren’t included in the numerical results due to their inherent  ambiguity
Rough Criteria Measurement Test(s)  Hole find Find hole location, locate 2 holes simultaneously, find  hole within hole (i
e
countersink) find all holes on  image  Hole measurement Measure diameter/radius of found hole(s), measure  circularity of found hole(s), measure concentricity of  hole within hole (i
e

countersink)  Edge detection Find edges in the image, measure edge location  Line  detection/measurement  Find line(s) in image, find line start/finish/crossover,  measure line length  Blob location/matching Score matches for blob(s) in image and locate  Pattern location/matching Score matches for pattern(s) in image and locate,  rescale pattern and find with measured scale change,  track a moving pattern (if live-video capable)  Calibration/ Accuracy Calibrate image using feature/grid, validate calibration  on other tests, test for sub-pixel accuracy  Colour detection Locate areas of primary colours in image (RGB+byte  value)  Text detection Read printed and handwritten text  Live video processing Record inspections per second  Scripting/automatic camera  setting  Write scripts and test automatic focus and exposure  Setup time/ease of use Record time spent working and difficulties encountered  Table 5: Planned tests  The details of the parts to be used would set the exact parameters of the features to  be inspected
The most important element for comparison was making sure that the  same inspections were carried out  6
2 Programming  In order to perform the tests, the system first had to be setup and programmed to  carry them out
The processed differed for the industrial vision systems and open  source systems

The industrial systems featured GUI’s and simple drag-drop  features to handle setup within their software, while the open-source libraries  required creation of some new software from which the inspections could be setup
1 Cognex Setup  Inspection in Cognex systems is setup on a PC, and then saved to the flash memory  in the camera, where an on-board processor carries out the inspection without the  aid of the PC
Inspection setup involves connecting your PC with Intellect software to  the camera over TCP/IP (Ethernet)
Once you have a suitable IP address and are  connected, you can start setting up tools for inspections
Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 15 of 27  Tools are applied to the image by dragging them from the tool box onto the screen
There are a wide range of tools available, e
g
hole measurement, line detection, blob  matching
These tools have some basic settings that can be changed via the GUI (for  example the area they cover)
More advanced setup is done through a set of menus  unique to each tool
In these, the user can set the details of the tool
If the advanced tool features still aren’t flexible enough, there is a scripting  functionality that can be used
This allows the user to write scripts that can call tools,  edit tool parameters and react to inputs
While this doesn’t allow the user to perform  inspections that aren’t already represented by tools in Intellect, it does give a range  of options for tool implementation
For the purposes of the AMRC tests, the inspections were setup separately
Within  the software, multiple sets of inspection tools can be stored as Jobs
When the  correct ID is transmitted, that particular job (and therefore set of inspection tools) are  called
Once the inspections are setup, they are saved to the flash memory on board the  camera unit via a button in the Intellect program
From here, a simple Ethernet  command can trigger image capture
Figure 5 : Intellect v1
1 Interface, example of inspection for black circles  6
2 Scorpion Setup  Scorpion Vision is setup and performed from the Scorpion Vision software suite on a  host PC

The camera is connected to this either through USB, Ethernet or FireWire  connection, and the software accesses the camera data via the camera’s PC drivers  (underlying Operating System software that turns raw hardware input into computer  readable data)
Due to the variety of hardware available, initial setup on Scorpion is slightly more  complex than Cognex
Once it is setup it works in a similar fashion
A GUI allows  tools to be dragged and dropped onto the inspection area
A sidebar allows for  customization of the parameters of tools
In general, the process is similar to Cognex,  although the GUI is different (see Figure 5 and Figure 6)
More complex inspections  have to be done via scripting
Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 16 of 27  Scripting in Scorpion vision is done in the Python programming language
The scripts  can alter tools, create new tools, or be called by tools to perform extra inspection  features
For the AMRC tests, scripts were not needed except for some data format changes,  as every inspection required was covered within the standard inspection tools
Once  setup, the inspections are saved in a file on the computer that the Scorpion Vision  program can run when prompted
Figure 6 : Scorpion Vision v9 Interface, example of inspection of a washer (circle in  circle)  6
3 AForge
NET Programming  AForge
NET is a library rather than a fully featured program in its own right, therefore  a new program had to be written using the library to setup the inspections  themselves
Since AForge
NET is a C# library, the Microsoft official C# IDE: Visual  Studio was used to code the program that would run the inspections
To use the AForge
NET library, it first had to be imported into the program and IDE
This was relatively simple to achieve, and just required adding reference to the library  file into the project in including it in the build for the project
From here, various features of AForge
NET could be called on in code

For example:  To find a circle, the programmer can use the SimpleShapeChecker class to check if a  circle is found, and if it is what it’s position and size is:  SimpleShapeChecker shapeChecker = new SimpleShapeChecker();               if (shapeChecker
IsCircle(edgePoints, out center, out radius))       //Work with circle data (draw on display to user etc)  Document No
Revision No

Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 17 of 27  This code allows the programmer to enact a circle-finding routine with a simple line of  code, rather than the extremely complex pixel-by-pixel comparison it would take to  program it manually
This functionality greatly decreases the time and programming resources needed to  perform vision tasks
However, it is still necessary to build a program for this  framework to run within

Using the SimpleShapeChecker example, in order to  perform this code, it has to be called in the program (by an event such as a timed- trigger or a user selection in a GUI), and passed a filtered image from a file or  camera feed to work with
This means the available functionality and GUI layout is dependent on the  programmer, which was the AMRC for these tests
The program created was made  to specifically perform the tasks detailed in the testing criteria where possible
The interface developed for this program can be seen in Figure 7

In order to make it  as quickly as possible, the interface was kept to a bare-bones layout: the radio  buttons on the left can be selected for different functions, and any interface elements  needed to setup that inspection appear around the camera feed when the correct  radio button is selected
Figure 7 : Programming and User Interfaces for AForge
NET Program (showing Edge  Detection on AMRC logo)  6
4 OpenCV Programming  Like the other library, AForge
NET, OpenCV required the creation of a program by  the AMRC in which the OpenCV library was incorporated
OpenCV is designed to be  incorporated into a program written in C++, a widely used high-level programming  language
C++ is an object-orientated extension of the language C, one of the oldest  and most popular programming languages
C++ is often used in machines due to its  very high efficiently compared to other high-level languages
There are several ways to use the library and link it into you C++ program
At the  most basic level, you need the correct files on your computer and the correct  references in your code to point to them
To make this easier (since references to the  multiple files of the library can be confusing to implement), it also has an  implementation in various IDEs
For these tests, it was programmed using the Visual  C++ Express IDE from Microsoft, with OpenCV added as a resource to the project
It  is worth noting that once compiled, the method of implementing the library makes no  difference to the end program’s performance or functionality
The library was used in much the same way as the AForge
NET, but with the built-in  vision functions of the OpenCV library called to simplify the process of inspection
The functions in OpenCV are not exactly the same as in AForge
NET, but with them  the AMRC were able to produce software inspections detailed in the testing criteria
Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 18 of 27  Figure 8 : Programming Interface for OpenCV Program (showing on pattern detection  on paper)  6
3 Testing Rig  In order to run fair tests, a rig was required to control the conditions the test would  take place in
As the AMRC was interested in the vision properties of the system,  conditions that affect image quality were the most important to control (such as  lighting conditions)
For this reason a simple, low-cost box was designed that would provide a small test  area where the lighting was entirely controlled and consistent

It would have been possible to simple use a set of fixed images to perform  inspections on, but it was decided, from the AMRC’s previous experience setting up  vision systems, that true live feeds from an actual environment would provide a more  suitable comparison to an industrial situation
The final testing box size was determined by the optical range of the cameras and  lens available in the project, and by the size of the parts which were available to  measure

Taking these into account, a testing rig was built out of wood to a size of  300x250x600mm, which would allow the parts to fit and all the cameras to be  mounted with room to spare for cabling and lighting
In order to provide a solid light that was flicker-free LEDs were used to front-light the  part
LEDs provide a strong, wide-focused light that doesn’t have a high-frequency  flicker as they are powered by a consistent DC supply

Frosted glass and focusing  lenses were obtained in case they were required to generate a more suitable light  source, but upon testing the system it was determined that the images produced  could be fully inspected with just the raw LED light

The mounting brackets consisted of extruded aluminum, which was first bolted to the  rig interior and was then drilled in several places, to allow a part to be bolted to it,  fixing that part in place
Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 19 of 27  Figure 9 : Unibrain and test piece in Testing Rig  Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 20 of 27  7 Testing  The first stage of the testing was to find a suitable part on which to perform the tests  detailed in the testing plan
For this, a part with known feature sizes was required
The parts chosen were measured earlier on the AMRC’s CMM
This is a  measurement device with a stated accuracy of 5 microns
This was the most  accurate and reliable part that could be obtained with the budget of the project
5  microns on the scale of the part represented far less than the accuracy the cameras  could obtain based on the pixel density of the sensors and the area they would be  focusing on
Therefore, the CMM results (and the related CAD) could sensibly be  used as a reasonable baseline measurement to which the camera based  measurements could be compared

This part can be seen below (Figure 10) with  markings for the various parts that inspections would be carried out on:  Figure 10 : Diagram of main test piece  1 These sides are used for edge detection, distance between and length  measuring tests  2 These through holes are used for multiple hole finding methods and  distance between hole checks  3 This partial-depth hole is used for doing a hole find on a matching  surface (the surface is also reflective to make this more difficult)  4 This lozenge of removed material was used for a blob find

The holes  were also used, to allow the blob tool to align another tool (the hole find  measuring tools)  5 This countersink allows the testing of a hole-within-a-hole inspection  Table 6 : Key for Figure 10  Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 21 of 27  In order to make the test comparisons fair, the camera systems had to see the  entirety of the part for each inspection
This leads to greater percentage errors on  very small elements (such as holes) than if an ideal lens and viewing zone were  chosen to inspect a single element

However, it allows for a more direct comparison  between the CotS cameras (with fixed lenses) and the industrial systems (that would  reduce the viewing range with a lens to increase pixel density and greatly decrease  percentage error on a single inspection)

 Test on different material (hole find on titanium block)   Pattern matching (using AMRC logo)   Tracking (of pattern matching)   Calibration (through the obtaining of actual measurements for tests above,  instead of pixel measurements)   Colour detection was done on various web-cam scenes as a proof of concept  on camera systems that were able (but accuracy was not measured, due to a  lack of a colour calibrated target)   Live and triggered image capture was carried out on all systems where  possible, and the available inspections in both modes recorded
Text detection wasn’t performed during the tests
This was due to any process of  doing so using the functions of OpenCV and AForge
NET been based on the pattern  matching functions
This would require setting up of a considerable library of letters  and fonts, and a large amount of coding to attempt handwritten letters
Therefore the  word detection test was deemed as beyond the scope of the project
1 Measurement Calibration  In order to get measurements in units such as millimetres, rather than pixels, a  calibration was performed
As well as converting to real-world units, this also allowed  the software to make up for any lens distortion to some extent

Lens distortion often  causes measurements at the extremities of an image to become less accurate; a  calibration can help to reduce this by producing a compensation factor produced from  inspecting a known calibration artifact, a feature of known size, or a calibration grid  that reduces or removes the negative accuracy effect of the distortion
The accuracy  of a calibration is given by the software in microns and based on the pixel size and  the distance between the calibration features
However, the end effect of calibration  on final result accuracy is more complex and difficult to quantify due to possible  accuracy and image quality variation over the area of an image

Revision No

The results in  these tables represent the results of repeated tests averaged out, with the average  error on successful inspections recorded as a percentage
Each test was repeated 3  times
Other tests that don’t have percentage errors are included as pass/fail tests

1 Setup Challenge  Outside of the results listed, there were other elements of the setup and usability of  the solutions that, while without measurable metrics, are important in deciding the  viability of a vision system for use in a project

To offer some viewpoint on the  complexity of setting up the vision solutions used here, a simple record of the time  taken to setup each system was noted down, as well as  comments on the  Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 25 of 27  programming style and approach the AMRC encountered using each system, to give  the time taken some context
It is worth noting that the Open Source systems will  naturally take more time and effort, as they are libraries while the 2 industrial systems  are already programmed into pre-made suites
Cognex Intellect: Time Spent ~ 4 hours   The Cognex system has been used extensively by the AMRC for a variety of  inspections in the past, and therefore setup was relatively quick and hassle free
For  a first time user the included documentation is extensive and the interface tools quick  to setup via a drag-drop interface
More advanced inspections (such as altering the  advanced settings or adding a script for inspection) could prove more time  consuming without experience in using the system
Due to the use of only one  specific piece of camera hardware a large layer of complexity, and therefore setup  time, present in the 3 other systems tested was removed

Scorpion Vision: Time Spent ~ 8 hours   The Scorpion Vision software has also been used multiple times by the AMRC in  previous projects, so development time was shorter than it would be for an unfamiliar  user
Setup time was increased from Cognex as the general interface was more  complex
This was partially due to Scorpion Vision’s use of multiple cameras during  testing and the related setup, and the variety of images that could possibly be  processed
The built-in tools covered everything required without extra scripting,  which made the inspection setup quick once the initial setup was done
The included  documentation was adequate and phone support was available when required
OpenCV: Time Spent ~44 hours   Unlike the preceding two systems, the AMRC had to use OpenCV as a framework to  develop our own vision system software
This lead to a longer development time as  the GUI and underlying code had to be created by the AMRC
In addition, the AMRC  was unfamiliar with OpenCV so it had to be learnt from scratch
The AMRC found the  online documentation (at the time of the project) to be reasonably deep and  comprehensive
Examples could be found that made some of the less intuitive  elements easier to understand
However initial setup of the system on a PC  (involving changing the PC’s environmental variables) was more convoluted that any  of the other systems tested
The C++ programming environment also required more  work and time to add a GUI to than the C# equivalent in AForge
NET (although a it  could be encompassed in to pre-existing GUI frameworks if available)
Overall this  was the most time consuming system to setup of the 4
AForge
NET: Time Spent ~30 hours  As with OpenCV, AForge
NET was both unfamiliar to the AMRC and was only a  framework that required a program to be created on top of it
The documentation  wasn’t quite as extensive as the other systems, and examples were harder to find  online (at the time of the project)
However the setup and install process were much  easier than the OpenCV equivalent, making it simple to include in a C# WinForm  project
This also enabled the AMRC to make the GUI much faster, thanks to  Microsoft Visual Studios drag-drop IDE environment for creating interfaces
The  programming difficultly was similar to OpenCV for AMRC staff, with experience of the  language and vision systems, but not the library itself
Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 26 of 27  9 Conclusions  Overall, both industrial and open-source of vision systems have shown different  strengths that would be useful in a variety of contexts
The results show that open- source solutions can give good, and theoretically equal, accuracy results when  compared to industrial solutions
They can also do this at a no up-front price

However, they also have notable weaknesses compared to industrial solutions, since  they require considerable more time and effort to program, and don’t offer the  guaranteed reliability industrial software does
This project’s results show a similar set of pros and cons regarding CotS camera  hardware
The cameras tested that showed excellent performance-to-cost, were  better at colour imaging than most industrial cameras and offered very high pixel  density comparatively

However, they were less accurate devices without  considerable effort applied to the image, required more tuning to match any given  industrial environment, and crucially lacked the ability to change lenses
From these results, it appears that open-source vision systems offer a low-cost way  to test an advanced vision setup that would be very useful in low TRL research
Open source software would be a good low cost way to experiment with new  methods not easily accomplished with existing on-the-market technology
However,  using open-source software and CotS hardware greatly increased the effort required  in programming, which increases cost through man-hours
Also open-source systems  lack the guaranteed 100% reliability and trust in measurements required for use in an  industrial shop-floor environment
Within the context of the research done by the AMRC, both open-source and  industrial systems have viable uses depending on the TRL of the project
Open- source software would be more viable if the work done in this project was extended  to remove the high effort barrier to get the software programmed and implemented
Document No
Revision No
Page  ABG076–AMRC–RP–140617A–01 01 27 of 27  10 Possible Future Work  There are several possible branches of work that could be done to extend this  project
Firstly, both the open-source software coding and the testing procedure  developed could be used to create standards for future vision system creation within  the AMRC

These standards could consist of coding standards to ensure vision code  is easily understood and cross-compatible across developers, and testing standards  to produce a fixed set of tests and metrics that could be used to determine the  suitability of vision systems to tasks before fully integrating them
Secondly, the testing done in this project could be move onto more complex tasks  that aren’t yet commonly used in industrial applications
An example of this would be  stereo-vision, a relatively new technique that uses 2 camera feeds and software to  produce 3D inspection data on a scene or object

Many of these more complex tasks  have become possible due to the rapid development of computer processing  capability; therefore they are at a lower TRL level and might be less well developed  in industrially approved systems, making open-source based solutions more viable
Thirdly, the testing done could be extended over more cameras and possibly other  camera-related systems

New sensors such as the Microsoft Kinect and the Leap are  not strictly vision systems, but often contain cameras in conjunction with other  sensors based on similar technology (such as a CMOS or CCD light sensor tuned to  pick up on infra-red light) to perform similar inspections
This could also tie into the  previous point, as most of these sensors are based on adding 3D inspection  functionality without the complex and time consuming code required in stereo vision  systems
Finally, if an open-source vision solution were to be used in an industrial test-bed, it  would need to be properly integrated into a machine
Industrial vision systems have  this functionality, but it would need to be developed for the open-source derived  software

Several network and communication systems exist for machines, and  developing a middleware that would be able to turn results from a low-cost camera  into a format that could be transmitted efficiently over the majority of these networks  would be a useful development for rapid testing and deployment of these systems in  the future

RP Revision 14 (June 2017)  Executive summary  The work performed for this report was developing a remote support system for physical assets and processes that  improved upon the current offerings in industry, namely phoning a call centre or arranging a callout
Some previous  attempts were taken into consideration, Microsoft’s Skype for HoloLens and previous work carried out at the AMRC as  a part of a Doctorate Engineering program
The system developed used mobile AR and VR technologies produced by  Google, Tango and Daydream respectively

The Google Tango AR application allowed a highly detailed, 3D scan mesh of the physical asset to be produced, the  user could then place markers upon the scanned mesh to highlight regions of interest, annotations could be added to  give further detail into why the user believed that area to be an issue, and an image could be taken and also attached  to marker
This information is then uploaded to an FTP server and a Mongo Database
The supporter, using the  Daydream VR application, can then download the data and view the scanned mesh, look and interact with markers to  see the annotations and images attached
The remote expert can also place their own markers and edit ones already  uploaded ones

This is an improvement on current support offerings because it contextualises the problem for the support, rather  relying on the user being able to articulate their problem to the support in enough detail

Instead the supporter can  virtually look at the whole product and any components that could be causing the issues, to determine the possible  cause of the issue and different possible solutions to the problem

It is also a much more efficient use of expert’s time,  instead of having to travel to each client individually to look at the physical asset, the remote expert wouldn’t even  need to leave the office to be able to provide at least a little support to try to alleviate the problem

RP Revision 14 (June 2017)  1 Introduction  Remote Support is used across a wide range of different industries, for many different types of  products

These services have typically operated in a similar fashion throughout their existence,  but recent advancements in a number of fields could potentially allow these services to finally  move forward and provide more accurate help
1 Current Offerings    1
1 Call Centres  Everybody has been there at one point or another, some kind of purchased product, for whatever reason, no longer  works, doesn’t go together properly or is just simply broken

The instruction manual has been consulted, which was  no use, Google returned no useful information and all troubleshooting methods have been exhausted to no avail;  there remains one option: Calling support
There are a wide number of reasons why these services are less than ideal
Firstly, they are almost always conducted  over the phone or via an internet chat system

This is an issue because it relies on the user, whom is very rarely  knowledgeable about the product they are having problems with, being able to articulate the issue they are having  well enough so that the supporter can build a mental picture in their head of the scenario, determine likely causes and  solutions to the problems, and then feed this information back to the user for them to carry out the fixes

Secondly,  these services are often outsourced to different countries, which can potentially affect the quality of the connection,  and it means that the supporter you are speaking to will probably not have the same first language as you, which  could potentially introduce language barriers to the situation

Lastly, the item you are having trouble with could be  one of tens, hundred or maybe even thousands of items produced by that company, meaning that it is very unlikely  that the supporter will be an expert or have specialist knowledge about the particular product you are having  problems with
2 Call outs  The alternative to calling a support line is to arrange a call out
This is when the client and the company who produced  or supplied the product organise an appointment for an expert to come out to the client and fix the issues themselves

While this is the most efficient method to fix the problem itself, as the expert can troubleshoot more effectively  potentially using specialised tools and software, it also has a number of fairly prominent drawbacks

Call outs can be expensive for the supplier or producer as they are losing the productivity of an expert for a number of  hours, and in some cases they can also be expensive for the client as a charge may be incurred
The number of experts  that a company will have available is limited, which means that the next available appointment slot could be the next  day or the next week
This is time consuming for the client and could have prominent repercussions if, for example,  they are an SME and one of their main pieces of equipment is no longer functioning

This means that for the duration  of the time spent waiting for the expert to come to them, they wouldn’t be able to produce anything, so they will miss  order deadlines and this will have a knock-on effect by delaying the rest of their deadlines too

3 Computer Remote Support  Over the past decade or so, the computer industry and companies operating in the field, have been able to move on  from traditional support services, due to advancements in Internet speeds and software
Rather than just being on the  phone or on an internet chat with the user, Computer Remote Support now allows the supporter to remotely connect  to the user’s computer and take direct control of it

This means that the problem the user is having is now  contextualised for the supporter, he is able to see first-hand any error messages that occur and the chain of events  Document Revision Page  ABG3016-RP-171128 Released 7 of 12  Confidential
© 2018 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017)  that leads up to the messages or program crashes occurring

The supporter is then able to analyse the user’s  computer, look at and directly manipulate the system to attempt to solve the issue and all the while they can be  talking to the user, explaining what he’s doing as he’s doing it, which means that if the problem reoccurs in the future  the user would have a much better chance of solving it themselves

This level of presence has benefitted the computer industry by being able to provide a more efficient and a more  precise way to help end users solve their problems and make much better use of expert’s time by removing the need  to travel to each client individually
Essentially, the direct control of the system alleviated most of the problems  associated with the remote aspect of the support

The main focus of this work was to investigate whether or not it is  possible to bring this presence to physical products and processes, as being able to see, walk around and interact with  the problematic product would allow for an improved support service
2 Previous Work  At time of writing, and to the best knowledge of the author, there have been two attempts at  trying to improve remote support services for physical products and processes
One is an offering  from Microsoft integrated into their HoloLens device and the latter was work carried out as a part  of an doctorate engineering program between Rolls-Royce and the Nuclear AMRC
1 Skype for HoloLens  With the release of Microsoft’s Augmented Reality (AR) device, the HoloLens, a Cyber-Physical presence in a scenario  was now possible

The software utilises the camera suite of the HoloLens to allow the supporter to virtually draw onto  user’s view to show them what they need to do, whilst talking to the user to explain the tasks simultaneously

While  enabling the supporter to see what the user sees using the camera of the HoloLens does provide an improvement to  the support service as it contextualises the problem for the supporter, is also somewhat limited

A certain degree of  instructions between the user and the supporter is still required for the supporter to be able to see exactly what they  need to, interactions remain limited, the HoloLens is not widely available, the device is expensive at £4529 for a  consumer model, and the program itself is not extendable in any way
Figure 2-1 depicts an example scenario of the  software being used
Here the supporter, in this case a father, is showing his daughter how to fit a U-bend
Figure 2-1 Microsoft’s Skype for HoloLens demonstration  Document Revision Page  ABG3016-RP-171128 Released 8 of 12  Confidential
© 2018 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017)  2
2 Low Cost Remote Support  As a part of an engineering doctorate program in 2016 at the Nuclear AMRC a Low Cost Remote Support system was  developed
This system allowed a Bi-directional link to allow communication between a Manufacturing Cell and Virtual  Environment

The system used a large frame to house an array of Microsoft Kinect sensors, to detect the location of  work inside the cell, and projectors to display work instructions and information on to a wing skin

The Kinect sensors  were used to show the positon of the worker in the virtual environment, which could be viewed by a person in Virtual  Reality (VR) and he could then point virtual lasers at regions of interest (ROI) on the physical wing through the  projectors
While this was a good  attempt and implementation to solve  the specific problem, it was also  limited in number of ways

The frame  for the Kinect sensors and projectors  was large and heavy meaning it was  far from a mobile solution, it was a  bespoke solution to a particular  problem, it required a calibration  process and if it was to be extended  to a different scenario it would  require an entire virtual scene to be  created for that specific problem

Figure 2-2 Frame and Wing Skin  3 Remote Support  For the Remote Support system implemented in this work, three salient qualities were identified  to ensure that it was an improvement over current attempts
It then needed to be determined  what technologies allowed these aspects to be implemented into the system, and then the system  could be produced
1 Defining the Three Salient Qualities   Firstly, and most importantly, this system needed to be general
It was paramount that anyone could use this system  for any product or scenario
This was one of the benefits of the HoloLens system and one of the drawbacks to the Low  Cost Remote Support solution

Secondly, it needed to be a mobile solution so that support could provide on a wide  range of physical items and scenarios, for example underneath a car, looking at an entire plane wing or in tight and  confined spaces
Lastly, the system needed to be accessible, so using devices that people are already familiar with and  not bespoke solutions to particular problems

Generally speaking, when Remote Support is needed it is rarely going to  be in a pristine laboratory or factory, it would be needed at the inconvenient times and in the inconvenient places,  which was something that was attempted to be captured in these three qualities
Document Revision Page  ABG3016-RP-171128 Released 9 of 12  Confidential
© 2018 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017)  3
2 Solving the Three Salient Qualities  3
1 General  To solve the generalisation problem, a VR scene needed to  be dynamically generated for a contextualised system
To  be able to do this, a device needed to be used that allowed  a detailed 3D scan of the problematic physical asset to be  produced

There are a number of different commercially  available products that would allow this to be performed,  from camera and depth sensor solutions such as the  Microsoft Kinect (1) and the HoloLens (2) to stereoscopic  cameras such as the Zed Space (3)

The results from the  devices ranged from unusable such as one produced by the  HoloLens, to very good produced by the Kinect Sensor,  however due to mobility issues with the Kinect needing to  be power and a PC to be connected to it had to be ruled  out

As the quality of the scan was so good, there was a  brief discussion about how to make the system mobile,  however then bespoke hardware would have been created  for the system which was something was to be specifically  avoided
These device at least proved that it is possible to  produce a detailed 3D scan of a physical asset that could  then be used in a VR scene
The main issue was the second  salient aspect, mobility

2 Mobile  The solution needed to be mobile so that it could be taken and used in any given scenario, which would not have been  possible if the user was tethered to a PC, like when the Kinect was used
The HoloLens is mobile device, however as  can be seen from Figure 3-1, which is a scan of a Caterham, the poor quality of the cameras meant that it was  unsuitable for the needs of this project
A mobile device that is familiar to almost everyone and has recently become  capable of performing the tasks required in this system is the Smart Phone
Since their inception in the early 1980s, mobile phones manufacturers have been driven by consumer demand for the  latest and greatest handsets

This has forced the manufacturers to keep innovating and pushing the boundaries of  mobile technology, whether they are pushing for the highest resolution screen, fastest chipset, most powerful  graphical capabilities or unique features that make the devices stand out from the crowd
These devices have also  become sensor rich with a plethora of different sensors integrated, meaning that a wealth of information is readily  available to be accessed by developers on these systems

3 Accessible  For the final salient quality, Accessibility, was important because of the need to keep the system useable to as many  people as possible without needing special training, and it also needed to be not a bespoke solution or piece of  equipment for a particular problem
With the sheer versatility demonstrated by smart phone app stores, it was clear  that Accessibility was also encapsulated in mobile phones

As they are so prevalent in society, the vast majority of  people already know how to operate one and use Apps for them, so a mobile phone became the ideal platform to  develop the Remote Support system on
Figure 3-1 HoloLens Scan  Figure 3-2 Kinect Scan  Document Revision Page  ABG3016-RP-171128 Released 10 of 12  Confidential
© 2018 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017)  3
3 Mobile AR and VR   With so much data being produced by users and companies in today’s civilization, one of the latest trends in the tech  sector is Data Visualisation

Two of the relatively new and popular methods are AR and VR, while these have been  possible on specifically made devices such as the Google Glass, Microsoft HoloLens and the HTC Vive, for a few years,  only recently has it been possible to incorporate them onto mobile devices, due to advancements in mobile CPU and  GPU speeds and power
1 Mobile AR  AR has, over the past year or two, become a major focus for the big hitters in the Mobile Phone sector

Both Apple  and Google who together have over 99% of the mobile OS market share (1), have made firm statements about how  they view the importance of Augmented Reality in the near future, producing platforms such as ARkit and ARCore  respectively
These software development kits are enabling developers to produce AR based apps for their devices
Google have also been developing a much more powerful AR software development kit called Tango (5)
Due to its  sophistication it does need a certain suite of sensors, specifically a Tri-Camera system that has a standard camera, one  dedicated to motion tracking and a depth sensor
This enables the phone to perform fairly sophisticated and advanced  AR techniques such as Motion Tracking and Area Learning
2 Mobile VR  Virtual Reality is also a focus for some mobile phone companies like Google and Samsung, producing the Cardboard  and Gear VR systems

While this is taking a very simplistic approach to VR, it’s also much more accessible than more  sophisticated fully fledged VR systems like the Oculus Rift (6) and the HTC Vive (7), with the aim of putting VR into the  hands of everybody
The ‘top-end’ of the mobile VR market is the Daydream (6) system also produced by Google
This  is an updated and refined version of their earlier Cardboard device
It has a 6 DOF controller for interacting with and  moving around the virtual scene
By simply inserting a mobile phone into the headset, the Daydream software is  launched and this allows the user to be in a VR environment
Using the phones Inertial Measurement Unit, orientation  tracking is possible

Phones that can be used in for Daydream applications must meet certain performance  requirements to ensure the apps will run on the phone, and this standardisation across hardware and software is  being driven by Google themselves
It’s also small, transportable and relatively low cost, satisfying the second and  third salient qualities discussed above

4 Implementation of this Remote Support system  For this Remote Support application it was believed that AR was particularly applicable for the user who was onsite,  with the ASUS Zenfone AR (9) the user is able to walk around the problematic item, produce a detailed 3D coloured  scan of the object, place markers upon the scan at regions of interest, annotate the markers to explain what he thinks  the issue is and also take an image of the part, attaching it to the marker
It was also thought that VR plays well to the  demands of the Remote support part of the system, being able to immerse themselves in a virtual world and see the  scanned object in a 1:1 scale
The scanned mesh was uploaded to an FTP server which could then be downloaded to  supporter using the Daydream system
He could then move around and look at the object in 360 degrees, view  markers placed by the supportee and place their own and add or edit annotations associated with each marker

He  could also see the where the supportee is standing in relation to the object and, like the computer remote support  system mentioned earlier, talk the supportee through what he believes to be the issue is and the solution to the  problem
The user in VR could also see the location of the AR user relative to the scanned object, and point at ROI  using a laser pointer which was visible through the AR user’s phone
Document Revision Page  ABG3016-RP-171128 Released 11 of 12  Confidential
© 2018 AMRC with Boeing
Template – AMRC
RP Revision 14 (June 2017)  4 Conclusions and recommendations  4
1 Benefits  Most prominently it is improving the quality of the remote support services that a company could provide, which  would result in an improved customer experience with the company
It improves these services by providing a more  precise method to identify a problem, explain why it’s wrong and provide solutions to it

As the system is based off  using smart phones, which the vast majority of people already know how to use, no special training is required to use  the system whereas if it was Hololens and HTC Vive based, this may be a requirement
It is far more cost effective  when compared to the original solution that was going to be implemented using the two aforementioned devices

It is  a completely mobile solution so you don’t need to be in an office or a VR space to provide the support, the supporter  could be anywhere so long as they had a reliable internet connection to their device
It also means that the support  could be provided at any time too, so long as they have the device with them
This system is also completely general,  so long as there is an item to scan, support could be provided for it

2 Limitations  The scanning of objects was occasionally difficult, particularly on matte black objects like the tyre tread, the Asus  Zenfone AR does have a specialized tri camera system, however if the comments by Apple and Google (10) about AR  are taken to be as serious as they say, these types of camera systems will be essential to improving the quality of their  AR platforms in the future
Daydream is also only available on Android devices however if Apple plan to support VR on  their phones in the future then cross platform operation should be feasible
3 Future Work  Firstly, voice is currently transmitted through the standard cellular network capabilities of the mobile device
Voice  calling can be integrated into the application using voice over IP (VOIP), providing greater control, allowing multiple  participants, and removing the reliance on a cellular network

A log in system would also be able to record who the  supporter and supportee were, the time of the support session and the issues raised and fixed during the session  which could be recorded into a database for future reference and potentially data tracking and analysis of the system  for further improvements
Additional attachments could be added to each marker, for example documentation  regarding the problematic part of the product
3D Geometry of different items could be imported to show how the  product should look
Freeform drawing could be implemented so either user could draw directly on the virtual object
Reports could automatically be generated based on the session between the user and the supporter
Multiple  Collaboration could be included so many people could enter the VR scene to collaborate and come up with solutions  to the problem
Lastly, with Offline Capabilities could be used so neither party has to wait until the other is free for  support to be given

uk Executive summary Current quality assurance methods for inspecting panels at EIP is a multi-stage process, which involves  operators  capturing  images  of  every  single  precast  embed with  a  mobile  device, before and after the rebar cage is placed in the mould, and senior members of the quality team validating it later on
This is a very manual process which is time consuming and prone to errors,  and therefore presents an opportunity to reduce costs and increase product  quality through automation
involves an operator inspecting a panel with a mobile device to click multiple images
This is time consuming and prone to errors

An inspection tool based on artificial intelligence (AI) has been developed to demonstrate the improvement in efficiency that can be achieved in the quality assurance process for inspecting precast panels

With data extracted from the Industry Foundation Classes (IFC) files and an image of the panel captured by an overhead camera, the demonstrated web inspection tool wascan becan be used to confirm the presence of the precast embeds and also verify that they are  in the correct locationwithin the acceptable tolerance level
Two demonstrators,  one at  Advanced  Manufacturing  Research  Centre  Factory  2050 (AMRC Factory 2050) and Explore Industrial Park (EIP) were set up to test the developed inspection tool

It was found that the AI models were able to correctly identify the precast embeds at AMRC  Factory  2050  with  approximately  95%  accuracy,  while  around  70%  of  the  precast embeds could be identified at EIP
This report includes details about the hardware and software components used to develop this inspection tool and also lists all its features
Opportunities to improve the accuracy and confidence of the AI models, by training on data from the production environment and using a different camera and camera mount hasve been discussed

and also Aadditional features that can be added to the inspection tool to improve productivity and quality, such as using a tablet device to capture images not visible to the overhead camera, automated shape checking of the panel hasve also been discussed
has also been to improve productivity have identified and discussed

uk 1 Introduction Panels  for  construction  projects  such as  Edinburgh Saint  James (ESJ)  and Thames Tideway Blackfriars are produced at EIP
The presence of the required embeds on these panels need to be verified and validated before the concrete is poured in and the panel is casted
Currently, a multi-stage quality assurance process is in place at EIP to verify and validate the presence of  the precast  embeds,  particularly  the anchor  pins
The current  process can be summarised as follow: 1
Operators on the shop floor clickacquire images of every single anchor pin before the rebar cage is put into the mould
Once the rebar cage is put into the mould, the process of capturing images is carried out again
Because the anchor pins are much harder to see once the rebar cage has been put in, labels are used for the anchor pins
A video is also captured as another form of evidence
Senior members of the quality team go through allanalyse the evidence collected by the shop floor operators to validate that all the anchor pins and other precast embeds are present on the panel

With  the  current  method  in  place,  not  only  are  the  shop  floor  operators  spending  hours collecting the evidence, but it also takes the senior members of the quality team another hour to go through all the evidence collected and then validate it
The current process is very manual, time consuming and prone to errors
This  creates an opportunity  to use AI  in detecting the precast  embeds for  verification and validation

Digitising  this  process  and  detecting  the  precast  embeds  using  AI  will  help  automate  the inspection process by verifying whether the correct number of the precast embeds are present on the panel, and also whether they are in the correct position

This report describes the inspection tool the web application developed by the AMRC in order to digitise and improve the efficiency of the current quality assurance process at EIPimprove the efficiency in the quality assurance process at EIP

The  aim  of  this  report  is  to  provide  the  reader  with  an  understanding  of  the  various technologies (hardware and software) used to develop the inspection tool, and also provide details  about  the  different  features  of  the  inspection  tool

uk 2 BackgroundPrimary software-based tools This section describes in detail the two primary tools on which the inspection tool is based upon: deep learning and processing Industry Foundation Classes (IFC) files of the panels
Using the combined output from two, the count and location of the precast embeds can be verified and validated
Section 3 describes in detail the development of the backbone of the web based inspection tool, which is an AI method called deep learning
The backbone of the inspection tool is an artificial intelligence method called deep learning, which is used to detect the precast embeds
Another important process is the parsing of the IFC files, which contains relevant information such as position and count of the precast embeds
The information from the IFC files needs to be extracted to use them in the web application

1 Deep Learning The backbone of the inspection tool is an AI method called deep learning, which is used to detect the precast embeds from an image captured by an overhead camera looking down at the panel
Deep  learning  is  a  subset  of  artificial  intelligence  and  is  inspired  by  our  brain’s  own interconnected network of neurons
In image based deep learning, tThe earlier layers learn simple features such as edges, whereas the deeper layers learn more complex features about the  object
It  is  widely  used  in  a  variety  of  applications,  from  self-driving  cars,  image classification to voice recognition
Detecting the precast embeds can be classed as a supervised learning problem
Supervised learning  methods  are  designed  to  learn  by  example,  where  the  labels  (ground  truth)  are available for all training and testing samples
In this case,, where the ground truths (position and the type of embed) are available along with the inputs (image of the panel)

The problem can be further classed as an object detection problem, in which the AI model is Document Page AROPCQA Report_IMG109450XXXX-XXX 11 of 46 Document reference IMG109450 Status Release Revisio n 01 Confidential

2 Parsing Processing IFC files Another equally important step is the processing of the IFC files
The IFC file of a particular panel contains data such as the CAD of the panel, along with the position and count of the different precast embeds
This data needs to be processed and extracted in order to be used in the inspection tool
IFC files need to be parsed in order to extract the information such as embed type, count and position for the inspection process
This is done with the help of open source tools: FreeCAD and ifcOpenShell
A Python program was developed  by the AMRC is used to do this, which uses open source tools such as FreeCAD and ifcOpenShell
The count and location of the precast embeds are saved as a NumPy array, which is later loaded onto the inspection tool according to the current panel being inspected
and the relevant information such as the embed count and position are saved in a NumPy file to be used by the web application
A CAD image of the panel is also extracted and saved
TheThe  Python  parserprogram  used  for  processing  the  IFC  files  runs  continuously  in  the background and watches tracks for changes in a particular folder
Doing so allows for an IFC file to  be  processed as  soon as  it  is  downloaded  from Trimble  Connect
When a new IFC file downloaded from Trimble Connect (discussed in Section 4
1) is available on that particular folder, the IFC file is parsed processed automatically and the relevant data is extracted, ready to be used in the inspection tool

2 Training and testing the model Training a model is the process of the model learning to map the inputs (image of the panel with precast embeds) to the output (localising the object and stating its class)
In order for the model to predict infer the presence of the different embeds in an image, it needs to be trained
During training,  the model  learns to map inputs  to outputs  using the training dataset
The  augmented  training  set  is  used  to  train  the  model,  and  the  model's  performance  is evaluated on the test set
Based on the results after training the models, it,  is tuned until the desired accuracy is achieved
The metric used to evaluate the models is the mean average precision (mAP)
This metric compares the ground-truth bounding box (set by the user) to the detected box (predicted by the model) and returns a score
Based  on  this  evaluation  metric,  the  model  is  tuned  by  the  process  of  hyperparameters optimisation
Hyperparameters are values which are used to control the learning process, and that which affects the weights and biases in a neural network
Some of the hyperparameters that were tuned to improve the performance were: 1
Learning rate: This hyper parameter controls the step size of how much the parameters (weights  and biases)  are being adjusted during the learning process
It  has  a value between 0 and 1
Choosing a very low learning rate slows down the training process, because the updates to the parameters are very small
On the other hand, choosing a number very close to 1 can result in an unstable training process
Batch size: This hyper  parameter controls the number of training samples that will be propagated through the network before the model’s weights and biases are updated

Having a very small batch size is computationally expensive and will result in a longer training time, whereas having a very large batch size results in significant degradation of the model’s ability to generalise

uk art model for object detection
YOLOv4 performed at the optimal speed and accuracy needed to perform automated inspection
The algorithm of choice was YOLOv4, which is a state of the art model for object detection
The models were trained using a pre-trained model on the Common Objects in Context (COCO) dataset
This method of using a pre-trained model as a starting point for a model on a second task is called transfer learning
Transfer learning speeds up the training process and also helps the model learn better in the new domain
Two different object detection models were trained, one for the anchor pins and one for the rest of the precast embeds
It was found that due to the differences in size between the anchor pins and the other embeds, two models performed better than one unified model
For the anchor pins, the training set comprised of 2,874 images and the test set comprised of 560 images
For the rest of the precast embeds, the training set comprised of 36,498 images and 4,707 in the test set

The number of images in the training and test set for both the models is given below: Table 1 Training and testing dataset size for the different embeds Embed type Training set Test set  Anchor pins model 2,874 560 Other  precast  embeds model 36,948 4,707 Note that the training and test set for the other precast embeds models is larger compared to the anchor pins dataset as there are 6 different types of precast embeds
For the anchor pin model,  the  training  set  was around 84% of  the  total  labelled data,  whereas for  the  other precast embed model, the training set was around 89% of the total labelled data
It is generally recommended to have at least 80% of the labelled data in the training set, as this helps the model learn and generalise better

3 Cropping, rotating and orientating:  Since the panels can vary widely in size and the camera field of view can include areas other than the panel itself, it is important to focus only on the panel and remove the surrounding areas from the image
This decreases the chances of the AI models detecting similar looking items outside the panel, and thus reduces false positives
Cropping the image also allows for faster processing and inference, as there are fewer pixels to process compared to the whole field of view
An image processing routine was developed using Python, which uses thresholding has been developed using Python to automatically identify the boundary of the panel and crop it
In the case where this is not accurate, the operator also has the ability to manually crop the image by drawing a box around it, if needed

Using the CAD overlay tool, a 2D depiction of the panel is overlaid on top of the image, thus helping the operator in making sure that  the orientation matches,  this  is  a critical  step to match the coordinate systems in the reference image and IFC file
The operator can rotate the image until the orientation matches

6 Tolerance checking  Dimensional Ttolerance checking ensures that the correct embed has been put in the correct position on the panel, according to the IFC file
The suggested acceptable tolerance levels are hardcoded presented to the userinto the program, but can be overridden manually by the user with the help of a built in slider
The default tolerance levels are in accordance with the ones stated in the quality documents used at EIP
Using the centres of the precast embeds obtained as discussed later in Section 5, individual embeds can be checked for their tolerance
This  is  done  using  the  KDTree  algorithm,  which  is  an  unsupervised  nearest  neighbour algorithm
The input to this algorithm are: 1
Coordinates of the precast embeds from the IFC file  2
Coordinates of the centres of the precast embeds inferred by the AI model
The algorithm finds the nearest neighbour of a particular point (precast embed centre in this case)
It also outputs the distance between the point and its nearest neighbour
This distance is then compared with the default acceptable tolerances for that particular type of embed and the operator is alerted accordingly

An example of the PDF report is in the Appendix IVII 5 Additional image processing  Once the precast embeds have been identified using the trained models, it is important to find the centres of the precast embeds in order to verify whether they are in their correct position and within the tolerance

The centre of the bounding boxes are not a good indicator of their actual  centres,  as  the  bounding boxes are often not  very tight  and often includes regions outside the boundary of the precast embed
Hence, image processing routines were developed to find the true centre of the precast embeds

Additional  image  processing  is  also  required  when  distinguishing  between  similar  looking precast embeds, such as distinguishing between the HTA-5030P-A4-150 and HTA-5030P-A4- 200 HTA 150/200 and
Another set of similar looks embeds are the HFV9_3260_GROUT_SLEEVE and BWT-GENERIC-FACE-HALFEN-DOWEL , as shown in Figure 5-1
Halfen Dowel/ Grout sleeve
These items vary slightly in size, and the AI models do not perform well in differentiating them
Hence, they are treated as a single class by the model and post processing is applied when they are detected in order to distinguish between them
Two different image processing routines, which vary slightly, are used to distinguish the two sets of similar looking embeds

The From a high-level view, the image processing routine to distinguish between them involves converting the area enclosed by the bounding box into an HSV image,  finding  the  distinctive  feature  colour  of  the  precast  embed,  applying  multiple thresholds  and  computing  the  area  of  the  region  of  interest
Once  the  area  has  been calculated, it can be compared against a set value to know its true type
A method which is less prone to errors and better has been discussed in Section 78

4 Discussion The differences in the models accuracy and confidence for the different demonstrators can be attributed to the following factors:  1
The models were trained solely on data gathered from AMRC Factory 2050, without any image  data  captured  at  EIP
Although  data  augmentation  was  performed  to accommodate for different lighting conditions, noise etc
, it is best preferable to have data collected from the production environment using the same setup (camera, light, and distance to the object) and train the models using that data
Upon investigation, it was found that the camera at EIP was not fully stable and was vibrating  due  to  gantry  crane  movements  and  windother  structural  vibrations
This affects the image quality, and deep learning models tend to be susceptible to blur and noise distortions
Using an anti-vibration camera mount will help stabilise the camera
results in the image not being clear, which affects the model’s performance

Due to the height at which the camera is attached, thedistance of the panel from the camera, the number of pixels in the region of interest (the panel) is around 10 times more for the AMRC Factory 2050 demonstrator compared to the EIP demonstrator
A higher resolution camera will  be preferable for the EIP demonstrator in order to get better quality images
pixel density of the objects were less than that at AMRC Factory 2050

Narrowing down the embeds search area:  2

Using  the  embedment’s  expected  position  from  the  CAD,  the  search  area  for  a particular  embed  can  be  narrowed  down  to  allow  for  the  AI  models  to  look  for  a particular item in a smaller search space
By doing this, the AI model can report back to the user the  confidence score  of  the  expected item type in  that  particular  location rather than the precast embed with the highest score
This is likely to improve the models performance
Using tablet camera to detect embeds on the vertical wall:  4

Due to the location of certain embeds, especially those in the vertical wall and rebar dense areas, the image captured by the overhead camera on the ceiling fails to capture some of the precast embeds
Using the tablet's camera, pictures of embeds on the vertical section or other sections not in the camera’s field of view can be clicked and embeds detected using the existing models
Although  this  functionality  has  not  been developed  yet,  it  is  proved  to  be possible as it can be seen in Figure 78-1

9 Conclusions This report states how an AI based inspection tool has the potential to increase productivity and improve efficiency in the quality inspection process at EIP

By using the data extracted from the IFC files and an image captured by an overhead camera, AI models can be used to detect the precast embeds and infer whether the correct number of each different type of embed is present on the panel
This can also be used to confirm the position of each embed and check whether they are within tolerance

This  report  states  the  different  technologies  (hardware  and software)  used to  develop  the inspection tool, and explains in detail the different features of the web inspection tool available such as integration with Trimble Connect, cropping the region of interest, bill of materials list, automatically generated inspection report etc
Two demonstrations, one at AMRC Factory 2050 and the other at EIP were carried out in order to assess the accuracy of the AI models in correctly detecting the precast embeds
The panel used for demonstration was a miniature version of the panels produced for Edinburgh Saint James (ESJ) project
The models were trained using images captured at AMRC Factory 2050
It was found that the AMRC Factory 2050 demonstrator had an accuracy of 97% and 95% for the anchor pins and the other precast embeds respectively
On testing the performance of the AI models at EIP using the same panel, the accuracy dropped to 70% and 73% for the anchor pins and other precast embeds respectively
These results can be improved by stabilising the vision system and also training the models on data captured in the production environment
Another test carried out on an actual  production panel for the Thames Tideway Blackfriars project at EIP resulted in the model being able to accurately detect 92% of the anchor pins

This  particular  model  was trained on a very small  dataset  (66 images)  captured at  AMRC Factory 2050, and was trained using the previously trained anchor pin model for the ESJ project as a starting point
Recommendations on how to improve the accuracy of the AI models by stabilising the vision system, using a higher resolution camera has been stated

Additional features that can be added to the inspection tool to further enhance its capabilities such as the ability to detect embeds not visible to the overhead camera using a tablet device, checking the shape of the panel,  colour  coding  similar  looking  embeds  haves  also  been  discussed
With  further development in training the AI models with the right data and improvement in the hardware, this tool can be deployed on the shop floor at EIP
To conclude:  The AI models need further development in order to increase its accuracy and confidence in the production environment

Additional  tools  such as  the  ability  to  capture  images  with  the  tablet  device  needs  to  be implemented in order to accommodate for regions not visible to the overhead camera  Document Page AROPCQA Report_IMG109450XXXX-XXX 36 of 46 Document reference IMG109450 Status Release Revisio n 01 Confidential
